Content:
Hello riders and mechanics.
To start off, I‚Äôll make it honest and simple. I love motorcycles and have had a few in my life time. But I‚Äôm not by any means an expert. I understand body mechanics for cars. Anyways, yada yada bla bla right? So above is a pic of what I would need to get info on. Firstly being a rider and not a mechanic, this is a CDI box? It doesn‚Äôt have any labels/model brand etc. I‚Äôm told that I need a new module, from my electrician (Spanish guy who doesn‚Äôt speak a word of English, and get around via his wife who translates) . He does general electrical work and doesn‚Äôt really specialize in bikes, though he‚Äôs good for it. He told me that ‚ÄúI had to get one of these‚Äù If you notice, my module or cdi box, whatever it is, has been scorched! I had flames under my butt, which I had to pull over and put them out. (Flames for paint work=üëç actual flames=üëé). This is for a 113 ci s&s motor. It‚Äôs not made on an assembly line, so there‚Äôs no way I can truly ever go shop at a Harley store. My question is 1)what is it? CDI? Do they catch fire often? it‚Äôs a six pin (actual screw driver looking heads and not flat). 2) where would a good place be to get these ? I see they apparently go for 900$ and as cheap as 12$, major difference in price clearly. Thank you for your help and happy riding

Vin

Of course I went far out of my way to live where the roads are not straight... and the people are ... üî•

As a lifetime G-force-junkie, the corners are everything ... straightaways are necessary evils that connect them. I strive to get my money's-worth from the entire tire construction, and for me said design must include high-G cornering as a major priority.

Content:
I have a 2006 KX450 that I've trying to get running for 8 months. When I kick it, it just turns the engine over and doesn't ignite. On occasion it'll backfire extremely loudly.

I've cleaned and checked the Carb, replaced the CDI and Ignition coil, checked valves (.007 and .008 on exhaust, .004 and .005 on intake valves), and a full top end.

The two mechanics I've taken it to haven't been super helpful. One said "the bottom end is ****ed" after trying to kick it over a couple times and the other said "tried to start unit and the engine is very tight meaning it feels like the engine is binding and isn't spinning freely".

I've taken out the engine and removed the side covers. The engine seems to spin very freely and I can't find any binding or such in the bottom end. The kick-start catches every 3rd or 4th kick, but the auto-decompression seems to be working fine.

I'm very close to just buying a new engine so any advise would be helpful.

Content:
Alright I have a 2006 genuine blur 150 (pgo 150). I have an issue where it cuts out after warm and will sometimes stall when it comes to a stop. It was my daily driver while in school and started out starting hard and led to cutting out after warm.

It takes a while to start with electric start but starts easier kick starting it. It runs fine and goes to max speed/rpm when cold but once it warms up it cuts in and out and will stall. If it stalls it‚Äôs almost impossible to start again.

I have been through the carb too many times, possible enricher problem but doubtful. I adjusted the valves to spec thinking it was a fuel mixture issue but didn‚Äôt help at all. Replaced intake boot and gasket thinking it was a vacuum issue but didn‚Äôt help.

Checking spark with the old plug it had spark when held to metal. I replaced the spark plug and the problem was gone. For maybe 20 miles it started and ran as it should and then the problem came back. Replaced the spark plug again and same thing. Has to be a spark issue right?

Could it be coil pack, stator? It gets good fuel from the tank and carb is great. Replacing spark plug resolves the issue but not for long. What‚Äôs going on?

Content:
My 1996 Honda Shadow V-twin 1100
has a valve cover gasket leak.
I have not cleaned the engine in nearly a year and there's probably one cup of oil spread out over the engine and baked on over the last dozen rides and 2000 miles.
I want to clean it off even if it will come back again later.
I don't want it to build up to the point that it becomes a fire hazard-- it does smoke a bit and stink when it's idling at a red light or stop sign.


So: How do you clean a really dirty greasy grimy motorcycle engine & undercarriage?

I've never used any spray on products.
Do they work?
Are spray on engine degreaser is safe for all the rubber and plastic parts on the bike?

I've always washed cars' exteriors with soap and water with a bucket,
but I don't think that's gonna cut it this time. There's too much stuff in the way to really rub away the greasy spots with my hands and fingers and a rag. There's a lot of oil and grease built up in places that my fingers can't reach.

I thought about taking it to a commercial car wash facility and using their high-pressure spray wand, but I wonder if that might be a problem with my compromised valve cover gasket.
I wouldn't want to spray high pressure soapy water my engine!

Content:
This thread is just a rant about my stumpy legs.

I'm not short at 5' 10" but my 29" inseam means most riding pants don't fit and most bikes outside of cruisers are too tall!

Last weekend I stopped in at a dealership to check out a bunch of bikes and found out that I can barely reach the ground on most.

GSX-8S... Too tall
XSR700... Too tall
MT-07... I could barely do it, but only because the suspension sagged under my weight.
SV650... I can't flat foot it but I can get the ball of my foot down, so it's doable.

I'd say anything with a seat height greater than 31" would be a real struggle, almost to the point of being risky. Lowering would be required.

Content:
Was doing 60 on bypass and bike started to loose speed very gradually but I could feel the power going, shortly after it slowed to 20 mph and sounded horrible then died after around half a mile and now won't start







I had a similar problem a few weeks ago where the bike suddenly slowed to 40mph and then picked back up to full speed, but developed a ticking noise after this, I check the oil after wiping the dipstick and winding back in it was dry when pulling out, though there was still some oil in the engine







After the previous issue i assumed this morning was obviously a seizure, however,



Bike is as easy to push as normal

Can turn the crank with a ratchet with little effort (sparkplug not removed for this)

Can feel compression stroke when turning crank

Can clearly hear starter motor turning over when pressing starter button


The bike was very low on petrol this morning and whilst it still seems to have some in there I'm wondering if it could've sucked some sediment in and choked the bike out? Haven't got a sparkplug socket as of yet but presuming that's the best place to start both to see if there's compression or if the plug is fouled?

Grateful for any advice given

Content:
bought this bike a year ago and rode it a lot last year. put stabil in the tank over winter.

this spring did not want to start.

primed the carb and it started and idled fine and would restart quickly after shutting off.

couple days later went to go for tide and cranked but no start.

did some internet research and figured fuel pump as this one has the extra wire for starting to the pump I am reading.

put a generic mr gasket fuel pump on and no start. I was getting gas to the carb and had gas in the float bowls when I opened the drains.

Went ahead and bought the factory pump and installed it.

Bike started right up ran and idled good. took it for a ride with no issues and good restart.

went to ride the next day and no start. Cranks but no start. If I can get it to start runs fine and restarts right away.

seems if I leave it over night I get a no start the next day

Title: Hello I'm Zuzu.
Author: Zuzu

Content:
Leo is a lovely canyon carver, comfortable highway mile eater, and highly efficient traffic dispatcher. While it seems to be gaining weight as a meander through my 74th year lapping the sun, I have no thoughts of giving up its favorable attributes.

However, it is quite unsuitable for keeping Piglet company when the spousal unit wants to take a short putt on our area's back roads. Dr Zee is just the prescription for that. He can follow her pace in 1st and 2nd gear with occasional shifts to 3rd when she 'opens er up' on paved stretches. Plus he is light and now, with the smaller wheels and tires, is easy for me to flatfoot and control at stops.

However, Dr Zee is a bit buzzy on the main artery in our area where the limits and typical speeds are around 70 mph. So I picked up a vintage BMW to fill that space AND to have a cool, relatively sophisticated and reliable bike playing a bit of a double role there.

THEN I tripped over a nice 2011 BMW F650GS that could replace both Dr Zee and the R90 for about the same price. I rode it today and agreed to buy it by the end of the week.

What a sweetheart. Spousal unit dreams it might replace THREE bikes, while I seriously doubt that, it is a whole bunch lighter than Leo and has some potential. I told her I am open to that as a possibility, but find it unlikely.

The new steed even comes with a zip-on tank bag and two aluminum hard cases... though if I was going far I still think Leo would get the nod. The 6-speed gearbox provides the right ratio for whatever I want at the moment and has a HUGE gear selector indicator removing all doubt. That and the analog gauges are all well thought out and the heated grip, signals and other switchgear look and work just like those on my R1200RT... familiar turf.

The GS putters along comfortably in the 15-25 mph range that Piglet enjoys, zips to 70++, cruises at 70++ without drama, accelerates quickly and easily in the 60-80mph overtaking zone, is at least 100 pounds lighter than Leo and feels well balanced at low and no speed. Its versatility has me thinking it could end up being "Jack" for Jack of all trades.

Content:
On my short list for this summer's Must Do is rolling on AMA members number one ranked road, The Beartooth Highway.
How could I live this close and not check it out?

I don't find events, crowds and such attractive, but I do find myself at least paying attention to the July 18-21 Beartooth Rally.
Included in the big weekend are poker runs over awesome roads, show, vendors, camping, iron-horse rodeo, bikes and bikers.

My view at this moment is that the highway rather than being uncluttered with great freedom of movement could be abnormally crowded during that time. I might be better off getting my ride on it done well before the rally.

Of course that does not preclude doing both. I suspect this might be like a Sturgis stepchild that should be experienced at least once per lifetime.

Content:
We are now 1 month away from this annual event that is now 12 years old ... and growing bigger every year so far.

This is primarily about a group of enthusiasts getting together and stylin' through the city on bikes.

It is also a fund-raiser for men's health issues. Though not as much fun to talk about as breasts, testicular cancer and suicides kill more people every year. The Distinguished Gentleman's Ride has donated $45 million towards programs working to reduce those negative impacts.

I am pleased to see that my closest 'big city' now has one being organized. My wife and I are seriously considering trailering our classics 1.5 hours each way to participate.

Hmmmm: It just occurred to me that I might try to set up "a test ride" for one of the new classic-styled bikes on that day.

For more information: The Distinguished Gentleman's Ride

Content:
New to this forum after lurking for a while. Great body of knowledge here for sure!üëçüèª
I‚Äôm a 60 something returning to the road rider. Rode most of the late 70s through early 90‚Äôs while in school and early career- CB400T, CB650, Sabre 750 and Zephyr750. Then for 30 years raced HS and MX - too many to mention. My user name of Noclutch is a reference to my few years of MTB racingü•µ- there ain‚Äôt no clutch to help you out of a jam.

Now I‚Äôve decided to get back to bikes that won‚Äôt beat me up so much, nor consume a whole day getting there, back and recovery. Lol. I‚Äôm not so much of a racer-type mindset anymore that I would want a full on sport bike- I wouldn‚Äôt/couldn't use it to its potential- too old for that, plus would my body wouldn‚Äôt appreciate it! But also not wanting to do the cruiser scene either- I ain‚Äôt that social. But group rides would be fine as long as they want to ride more than talk. I‚Äôll primarily be doing low population backroads on weekend mornings at a sane pace and some local errand runs.
While researching my new bike I‚Äôve been taking note of all the things that have, and haven‚Äôt changed. After much deliberation, I decided on this. And yes, the traction control and ABS are set to full nanny for now. It reminds me of the RZ 350 I kick myself in the butt to this day for not getting!


If you‚Äôre in the Ocala, Florida area maybe we‚Äôll cross paths üòä

Content:
Hello, I rebuilt my carb recently and it all seemed to go pretty well- disassembled, cleaned, replaced old parts with new, re-assembled with new gaskets.

After the rebuild I took it for a ride, it ran well enough, in fact, it ran almost the same as it had before I worked on it. I rode it back, parked it, and came out the next day to re-assemble the fairing, etc.

Oil had leaked out all over under the bike. I hadn't touched the oil plug or anything associated with it recently. When I looked more closely, it appeared that the carb had a leak (the carb and area around it were wet whereas they were not the day before), and my assumption is that the gas leaked out of the carb and somehow got down into the crank case, over filled it, and gas and oil leaked out- no other explanations made sense.

Anyway, I don't know enough about carbs to understand how that could have happened or which of the many wee parts I replaced to look at. Is there an obvious cause, or do I just get to disassemble and re-assemble the carb again, hoping that does it? Strangely, the fuel valve was set to 'off', but the tank was almost empty.

not sure it matters- my title says I have a '59, but the vin on the frame says it's a '64.

Content: I need to remove the carbs. I've done it before, and it's really difficult. The part that makes it most difficult is the filter box. It doesn't slide back far enough to allow the boots to clear the carbs. I hope there is an easier way. BTW, I have the factory service manual, and the Clymer manual, both make it seem like a half-hour job, and don't cover the things I'm mentioning. Several things I've done to make it easier, (but still not easy) is to remove the two screws holding the air box in the back, and removing the voltage regulator from the left side of the air box. This allows the air box to slide a little further back, but not quite enough to give enough room to slide the carbs out easily. I've been removing the boots, but it's quite difficult and I'm afraid I will tear one. Could removing the inner fender make it easier? Thanks for any suggestions.

Content:
First off I want to say I am not trying to call out any person or specific group here, this is just a general observation.

Most of my experience is with cars and car hobby culture, and sure people do all sorts of dumb stuff with cars and there is some misinformation floating around, but with motorcycles it seems to be on a whole different level, possibly several new levels.... It constantly amazes me how many competitively dumb choices it seems like are made so regularly in this already dangerous hobby. I mean we know it is a hobby you need to exercise care with, yet the amount of misinformation and just sheer overwhelming amount of WTFtitude I see on a regular basis blows my mind.

Ohh you removed your mirrors and/or front brakes from your street bike because you think it looks better? Really, you think that is a good plan? Even if you keep your front brakes you are sure you shouldn't ever use them unless it is a dire emergency then just squeeze as hard as you can and pray huh?

I know people are genuinely hurt by inattentive drivers, and whether you could have avoided it or not, it sucks you got injured, and I do feel for you, but also I seem to be constantly hearing stories where I am thinking stuff like:

I am sorry that guy cut you off and caused you to skid a few dozen feet then slam into him so hard you lodged your bike under their car because he didn't see you or failed to predict how fast your were going at a 2 way stop in town. But also.... How fast were you going to skid so far then hit a car so hard it was lifted up and slammed down on your motorcycle when the speed limit was likely 30-35mph? Have you been practicing threshold braking? Been keeping up with your front tire? Because something doesn't add up here....

Ohh someone hit you right as you were pulling out of your driveway and you got injured? I am really sorry to hear that, but also.... Why did you pull out right in front of a car? Were you expecting them to watch out for your safety and slam on their brakes to avoid hitting you?



There is just so often I am left shaking my head and honestly surprised casualty rates are not higher than they are in this hobby.
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
üèç General Motorcycle Discussion üèç

Content:
I always enjoy going out and completing unique Iron Butt challenges. This one was extra special and will always be my favorite certificate. Weather was terrible the whole time and I even had to make some adjustments getting to the cemetery where my dad is buried due to flood waters but was able to get it done. Here's the thing....he lived right on that corner where the road was flooded. Probably just 100 feet away. In a way it was sorta cool having to turn around in that spot that would always flood with big rains whenever I was a kid. Kinda felt like him saying, "it's not gonna be that easy today, kiddo!".

The unique combination of riding on our birthday, getting photos of signs that had our names, and visiting his gravesite made this one unforgettable and gratifying despite the terrible weather.

Content:
My favorite cornering practice 'track' is a 15-mile stretch of highway 93 over the pass between Montana and Idaho. In both directions there is a lot of double lanes (passing lanes) on the uphill portions ... on the Montana uphill, the whole curvy stretch is one lane down and two up. Both ways have very nice pavement on curves from 2nd gear sweepers into high 4th or 5th. I view it as a great place to develop my cornering skills - pushing closer to the edges so I have the confidence and practice necessary to tighten turns elsewhere if that is required in a tight spot.

Yesterday was my first outing on Leo for the year and I wanted to start with that bit of cornering practice ... building from conservative up to wherever reasonable caution took me on 2024's maiden RT ride.

I noticed strips of traction sand where the four wheelers had not dusted it off the road surface, but those patches were few, far between and never in my lines ... until ... they were.

Dang! I love those Michelin Road 5s.

I was leaning well into a right-hander with zero traffic. I was centered to the right edge of the middle lane (room to burn on both sides of me). Then I observed an unusual patch of sand on my trajectory - and I was already in it. Leo danced a bit, felt slightly loose, but tracked through it like a champ.

My community service completed for the day by moving that sand off the correct line, I greatly intensified my concentration on seeing traction sand patches before I felt them. One was enough - and that's exactly what I got. I also cut my ride short, turning around at the top rather than finding how well the Idaho Highway Department had done on sanding and cleanup of their share of my school room.

Tomorrow is the first Sunday Morning Breakfast Club run over famous Highway 12 from Lolo to Lochsea. I have to ride an hour of slab before arriving at the starting point which takes a little polish off that apple. I have decided to forgo this one and let the sportier guys and another week or two of regular traffic sweep the traction sand of the sweet corners up and over Lolo Pass.

Tip for early season riding where traction sand is use for winter driver safety: Be vewwy vewwy careful.

Content:
Exploring the Netherlands | Dutch countryside river run | Yamaha Tracer 7 |

Spring ride on the Yamaha Tracer 7 riding into the Vechtstreek following the river Vecht.
This is a beautiful part of the Dutch countryside with some nice little winding roads, small villages and great nature panorama's.

Filmed with the GoPro 12

Enjoy the ride, Jaamaan123


The Vecht is a Rhine branch in the Dutch province of Utrecht.
It is sometimes called Utrechtse Vecht to avoid confusion with its Overijssel counterpart.
The area along the river is called the Vechtstreek.

The Vecht originates from the city of Utrecht, where the Kromme Rijn stream forks into two branches: the Leidse Rijn/Oude Rijn branch to the west and the Vecht to the north.
Originally the Vecht branched off south of the city near the Roman fort Fectio, flowing eastwards around the city, but in the 12th century a northern shortcut was dug out.

The Vecht meanders north past the towns and villages of Maarssen, Breukelen and Nigtevecht, crosses the border into the province of North Holland, passes the city of Weesp and discharges into the IJmeer (Lake IJ, part of the former Zuiderzee) at Muiden.
The Amsterdam-Rijnkanaal (Amsterdam-Rhine Canal) was dug in the Vecht basin.

The Roman historian Tacitus tells us that in the first century CE a Roman fleet sailed due north down a Rhine branch, then sailed past Lake Flevo (now the Markermeer and IJsselmeer lakes) into the North Sea.
This could have been the IJssel, which the Romans connected to the Rhine themselves, or the river Vecht.
In the 17th and 18th centuries many country estates, known as buitenplaatsen, were built on the banks of the Vecht by rich merchants and administrators from Amsterdam.

Cicadas incoming: Billions of insects poised to emerge in double-brood invasion
The winged insects are set to pop out of the ground in the coming weeks in a rare synchronized event that last occurred in 1803.

I saw a hatch of these in Virginia about 17 years ago and they were everywhere. They don't live very long and if you get a bunch of them on the road, they could make it a very slippery ride.

With the billions or even trillions of Cicadas bursting on the scene with the double emergence in the southern USA this summer, things could get very slippery on the roads.

Content: I haven't take a long motorcycle road trip in several years, but plan on doing one this year, probably in June. I don't camp since my body does not take well to sleeping on the ground anymore. But even with using motels, which I know will be more expensive than ever before, I am reluctant to make advance reservations. Right now I am not at all sure of how many miles I will be riding in a given day. I'll be 81 in June and as I said earlier, have not done this in several years. So my guess is that I will only do about 300 miles before stopping for the night, but plan on riding until I start to feel tired and then will look around for a motel. The advantage of advance reservations would be to not have to worry about finding a place to stay, but it gives up the flexibility of just riding as much as I feel like riding that day.

Content: yamaha gt50 1974. Last time it worked was 20 something years old. Had the magnets and igniton switch broken, replaced them all (now i have a constant and pretty spark), but the iddle was terrible and no throttle. People sugested it was bad timing or something with the carb, checked the timing and it is on the only spot where i have constant spark and where it iddles(its as factory). Carb cleaned it 3 times ,each time thought it was badly clean (it was not), replaced the jets by brand new ones and new seal for the carb bowl. The issue is still there 0 throttle and bad iddle, now i think it might be a vacuum leak(i also replaced the air filter, anything that is obvious i checked) if its not a vacuum leak i'm honestly out of ideas.

Title: 2015 Suzuki C90 BOSS
Author: Super Coot

Content:
A very long story short here.
What a trip! I was 18, sis was 16.
Mom, 2-up behind dad, and sis 2-up behind me. Took the county roads down, and coastal 101 home. Mom wasn't too keen on going but caved. She wasn't all too happy in the frigid weather we ran into during the early morning Oregon high desert. She was a trooper though and rode out the entire round trip. She never ditched us and took a bus or plane home.
Now that I look back on the trip, often uncomfortable and grueling on those little 450's and just as often exciting and fun, it was something our family did together, and will always be a fond memory.

Mom began with a smile. Not sure that lasted long. Dad was smart. He had a fairing and windshield. I didn't because they didn't look "cool." I was the dumb one. Battled wind and bugs the entire trip.



On our way to California!
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
Motorcycle Stories

Content: Hello everyone. I recently got a 82' CB650 Classic and put some work into it. I have had the carbs rebuilt, new battery, new stator, new fuses, new spark plugs, valve adjustments, new tires, new petcock, air filter, and a few other things non related to operability. Since changing the stator I have had issues with it starting. When initially swapping the old stator out it started right up, but when I went to give it some gas it putters out and dies. I previously thought that this was a stator problem, not giving enough elec to the plugs. Someone else told method the polarity might be reversed so I swapped the black and white wires on the stator, but to no avail. Now that I have changed the stator it makes me think something else is up. The rectifier has been checked, and is in working order. Maybe the rotor itself has been demagnetized somehow? I dontknow what to do next and was hoping for some help before taking it to a local shop and spending more money I don't have. If anyone has any info it would be much appreciated! thanks

Content:
Model year make
Z1000 2008 Kawasaki

1. Initial problem - motorcycle not charging as voltage keep dropping during running on the road.

2. Troubleshooting - replacement of battery

3. Conclusion - voltage is still dropping battery not charging.

4. 2nd troubleshooting - replacement of stator and rectifier. At the same time also replace the clutch plate and friction plate as an extra bonus since I'm opening up the bike.

5. Conclusion - battery is charging as voltage is increasing and stabilize above 12.6volts ~ 13volt. However, after putting it down to gear 1 or gear 2 from neutral there's a knocking sound coming from the left side of the motorcycle.

6. Not sure what I did wrong. As Idk if it's the clutch or generator area was installed wrongly or is it something else.

7. Notes, why I'm confused is because the generator was on the left side, clutch is on the right side. But stator was charging the battery there was no knocking sound when running in neutral. Yet the sound comes in loud when I put it on gear 1 or 2. There's some resistance when I try to engage the gears. Knocking sound is heard when bike was stationary and engage onto gear.

Crash guard was not mounted back not sure if it's because of loose mounting point but I doubt it's that reason.

Need advice on where to tackle this issue. Or has anyone comes across this.

Content:
have a bmw k100 rs that hasn't run since 2019, i filled the tank up with gas and stabilizer to prevent rust in the tank.

other than that i didn't do much.

i read that you should put fresh oil when storing for a long time because oil turns acidic and can damage the engine.

I'm very skeptical of this claim and i think there is no evidence supporting it, am i wrong?


lets start with the shaft drive oil, my Toyota went from 2008, 200k, until a few months ago without a differential and transfer case oil change. no issues that's 16 years of running the car almost daily.


now, about the engine oil, how exactly would it hurt even if it turned acidic? what components could it damage just sitting there not running?


does anyone have evidence supporting these claims or is this just bro science?

to be honest i really can't be bothered to change the oil and spend some money on new oil that will have to be drained away anyways when the bike will come out of storage.


guessing there are no issues with the coolant turning corrosive and such?

anything else to do for this long term storage?

Content:
Hi guys, I‚Äôve recently purchased a Honda CBF 125 (2010). It had about 20,000 miles it was in good condition and worked perfectly fine.

Unfortunately I dropped the bike exiting a junction at around 5-10 MPH. This resulted in the front brake lever snapping in half and the front right indicator smashing, including the bulb. Apart from the broken indicator the bike still worked fine.

Later that day I‚Äôd started the bike up again and noticed that the neutral light wasn‚Äôt working. Upon further inspection I‚Äôd realised that now none of the indicators would turn on, the horn wasn‚Äôt working, the brake light worked but didn‚Äôt get brighter when the brakes were activated and the engine light which would come on as you turn the key to on no longer worked.

The bike is completely dead electronically until I start it. It still starts and runs fine. The brake lights still turn on and the headlight works. This is my first manual motorbike and my knowledge on repairs especially electronically is very limited so if anyone has any idea what the problem could be please let me know.

Side note: before I‚Äôd dropped the bike as I‚Äôd turn the key to the on position the bike would make a whirring sound (I think this has something to do with the bike charging system). As I turn the key to the on position I no longer hear that sound.

Title: New member
Author: Raja

Content:
Hey guys. Bought a 2012 Suzuki boulevard C50T as my first bike with 14,200 miles. Bought back in December 2023 , 26th iv out roughly 800miles on it in the first before changing the oil at 15000 miles. Everything seemed fine. Put another 2500 miles I'm at 17600 and iv used a few "berryman B-12 fuel treatments....3oz for the 3.5 gallon full tank. Less then recommended. And added new exhaust...cobra slash.. never got it tuned cause I like the backfire. But that was the first thing I did with the oil change. That's a little the back story...the problem (that we think is a problem) I'm replacing the clutch cause the clutch seems to have been going or just recently got worse. Either way we looked at the oil and noticed it's almost empty. Can't even see it in the sight glass. Oil pressure light isn't on so there is some oil in there...but we're not sure where it could have gone...

So we are thinking...

Option 1: the clutch has been burning up the oil considering I didn't know the clutch has been slipping till recently. The bike shifted funny since we bought it. But has gotten way worse.

Option 2: the engine just happens to burn oil at a higher rate then normal

Option 3: the berryman B12 screwed up the rings and I'm losing oil out the exhaust cause theres no clear wet oil spots anywhere else on the engine. The exhaust is black. It's been raining so we don't know if it's Texas moisture mixed with with carbon soot. It's practically strait piped and backfires almost on every time you roll off the throttle hardly any baffles at all.
Short of a compression test were not sure. See if this forum has any insight or suggestions of ways to cancel or verify possibilities.

Title: Scouting Anyone?
Author: Steadfastly

Content:
There is a trend that I consider to be from Japanese anime or something like that where sharp, harsh lines and high-contrast colors are replacing smooth, sweeping curves and graceful tonal transitions or single colors. It pushes me away from most new motorcycle designs and towards what might be called a classic look.

Aerodynamic design used to lead designers into smooth contours, but now something is driving these sharp edges and abruptly contrasting color accents. I'll take vintage over modern every time.

I made this picture to illustrate what I think of as a wrong direction in design... and why.

Obviously gentle curves are more appealing to me than sharp angles.

Now I don't mind the bike being as loud as it is but the backfire is irritating and I'm sure it's not running as good as it should. How do I go about fixing this, put on the missing AIS block plate? Can I return the bike to stock and put the PAIR system back on? Or are there other aftermarket option I can opt for? Title: 2003 Honda Shadow 750 ACE
Author: IndyJen

Content:
This has been a strange year. Last Fall I took my last ride of the year around November 15th, not expecting to ride again until at least mid-March. But we had incredible weather toward the end of February and I was out at least seven or eight times on one of my two bikes between that time and early March. Then Winter returned, and with a vengeance. More snow than we had seen in the last couple of years and cold, nasty weather almost every day. Now here it is April and it was still 26 degrees this morning. I'll be away for the total eclipse, but I am hoping that when I get back, so will riding weather. At my age I hate to see time go by where I can't or won't ride (I don't ride just for the sake of saying I got the chance to ride, if its no fun due to cold, rain, wind or whatever, then what's the point of riding?).

I turn 81 in less than two months. Right after my birthday in early June I plan on taking what well might be my last long motorcycle trip. Right now I'm not sure if I will head West from northern Illinois to South Dakota/possibly Wyoming, or head East to Dayton, OH to visit the USAF museum that I've wanted to visit for the last several years.

Title: Another test !
Author: BADNESS

Content:
Hi All,

New here but not new to cycling and the road. Recently I bought a 2003 Kawasaki EN500 Vulcan and we are restoring it, needing to find several parts:

1. Battery,
2. Carb rebuild kit,
3. Carb floats,
4 Fuel distribution tube, between the dual carbs

The Battery has unusual dimensions and most selling them use metric and I do not so measurements for this must be exact.

We ordered the carb kit which they advertise as "fits all years from 1997 to 2020, but it does not, so could only use about 3 parts out of the "universal" one they sent, Need the exact one!

The carb floats are bad so constantly get filed with gas, but can't seem to find these floats online,

The fuel distribution tube, taking fuel from the tank and distributing to both carbs, part metal, part plastic, and the plastic on the right side broke so is pouring gas everywhere so a huge fire/safety risk. I'm seeing this has a unique name which I do not know, therefore not able to find it.

Any help with me finding these parts is greatly appreciated!

Cheers!

TBNK

Content: I have been doing repairs on my 1985 GPz 750. I had trouble getting it to spark and it idled rough. I recently replaced my resistor caps and my spark plugs. I swapped out my starter solenoid and ignitor box. After some work I had it running again only to find out when I open my throttle up the engine starves and dies. It seems to idle alright, if anything slightly higher than normal, but it doesn't seem to match up with my tachometer registering almost no rpm when it sounds about where it would normally idle at 800/1000. I can give it a little bit of throttle and slowly work the throttle up but the sound of the engine does not match where it would normally register on the tach. I'm new to some of these bike repairs so I am at a loss for what to do and look for.

Author: BADNESS

Content:
Hello all; my first post here!

I have a 2020 SC c125 that I just purchased. It has 1200 miles on it and was serviced (First service) by the dealer at 580 miles. I noticed what sounds a bicycle with a baseball card clipped to the frame and that card contacting each spoke as the wheel turns (yeah, I'm old and we used to do this sort of thing in the 70's, as kids. I changed the oil for good measure, yet the valve train (or injector) noise remains. I adjusted the valves and I think there was a slight improvement. No noise at idle or WOT, but I can bring it on and higher RPMs (not redline high, mind you) when in-between rolling on/off the throttle - basically higher RPM, but not under load. I'm hoping someone here is familiar with the Super Cub c125 horizontal motor and can tell me if this is,

a) A normal characteristic of this motor (FI, valve train, etc.)
b) Something else that needs addressing (CAM chain tensioner, valves, tappets, etc.)

I asked the prior owner and of course, he said that noise was there from day one ("a" above).

If the consensus is defective CAM chain Tensioner, I was hoping to just drain the oil and pull the tensioner sealing bolt, spring, pushrod and pushrod head - and not have to pull the right case cover, flywheel, etc.

If normal, how can I quiet this engine some? Using 10w40, instead of 10w-30? Move from a 14T front sprocket to a 15T sprocket? Other?

Thanks for any tips or suggestions. Links about this (and the fix) would also be appreciated. I Google searched, and also YT, but didn't find much, aside from valve adjustment videos (and since it's not that...)
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
First Bike / New Rider
Title: Hello! Help needed to diagnose 2020 Honda Super Cub c125 engine noise...
Author: Jebinc

Content: I tend to fall in love with my bikes and take good care of them. I also tend to keep them for a long time and lot of miles. The last four street bikes were sold at 126,000 miles (1980 Kawasaki KZ550), 16,000 miles ( 2004 Kawasaki Ninja 250), 115,000 miles (2006 Kawasaki Ninja 650), 80,000 miles (2015 Honda CBR500) and my current bike, a 2022 Kawasaki Z650RS which has 19,000 miles). All of those bikes were nowhere near worn out, but because they were considered worthless by most people I had to sell them dirt cheap. I think modern, water cooled, fuel injected bikes to be pretty much like modern cars (which I also keep forever) and are pretty hard to wear out with reasonable use. What say ye?

Title: What do you consider high mileage for a motorcycle?
Author: McRider01

Content:
Shaft drive..
Automatic shift.. with paddle option.
Cruise control..
ABS..
5 gal. Tank.. min.
50 mpg min at 65 with saddle bags and camping gear..
Low seat height for easy weight management. Not GS, more cruiser low, but not quite that low.
Motor and tranny must be BULLET PROOF.
Easy maintanence on air, and oil filter, meaning not having to take tank off to get to air filter, or special tool to take oil filter off inside the engine.
Oh...easy valve adjustment (long intervals) meaning not every 6K miles.

Does it exist ? No it doesn't.
But it should.

Can somebody just build it already. Damn !

Oh, and while your at it...
make it a hybrid that gets 100mpg.

Hell. My 2016 prius gets 55mpg at 65mph.

And make it light weight.
Not alot of plastic.
If you must have plastic...make it where all the plastic can be removed in 5 minutes.

You guessed it... motorcycle manufactures are missing the mark.

Title: Suzuki K10/K11 wheel parts compatibility
Author: The Shake

Content:
It was 1967 in Burien, WA when my father bought his first and last Ducati, a 1967 Sebring 350.
"Hop on the back, son. I'll take you for a ride."

We ventured down the road a few miles, and it was instant 2-wheel love for me from then on. A person either loves to be on a bike or doesn't. Seems there is no in-between. But I wanted to ride one myself after being two-up with my dad, and on the road at that.

It's funny how we can recall the smallest details, and why. For me, the geometric headlight can was a focus for me. Seems like it was possibly a polygon. Weird me, taking in the shape of a headlight.

Yeah, so I wanted to ride that bike...any bike, on the street just like dad. "Dad, when can I ride this?" I didn't particularly like the answer. "In four more years when you get your license at 16, son." Ahhh, the pain! Four years is a week today, but a decade when you're 12 years old.

But all was not lost, as my dad moved the family out into what was then the country above Issaquah, WA on 2 acres with about 1K acres of dirt, an abandoned gravel pit, and forested trail riding territory right from our home. I had turned 13. So, 2-wheeled heaven came to me in the form of a very basic mini-bike my dad bought from a friend, used, for $40.00. I couldn't be happier! Other than chores, I was on that minibike every spare minute I had, rain or shine.

That started a thing which continues today at my ripe old age of 70 this year. The bikes got bigger as I made more money working part time through high school, and even did a short stint of flat track racing before I joined the Navy.

My dad never stopped buying and riding motorcycles either, and I was lucky enough to ride with him on many trips...just the two of us, when I retired from the Navy in 1998, and always with fishing gear on the back of our bikes. Dad became a deputy Sheriff in King County, WA at age 35, and one of his many positions was being a motorcycle cop when they put him on an AMF hog. He loved that job. The bike was in the shop a lot (AMF, right?). We rode in every weather condition you can think of, slept on the ground, in a parking lot, in motels, and even on picnic tables in a very wet park. We rode together until he was 77, when he decided he was pressing his luck. He passed 5 years ago. I'll miss the finest riding buddy and father that, IMO, ever existed.

Got a photo of dad here at 34 years old on his Ducati Sebring in 1967 near North Bend, WA. Note the Cig, boat shoes, T-shirt and no helmet! I think he could have doubled for Steve McQueen!
Photo is reversed. I took the slide in to make a print and they messed it up.

Cheers!
Breadcrumbs:
Home

Motorcycle Stories

Title: 98 Virago 535
Author: Confused-biker04

Content:
I'm almost 50. I took took the MSF course in December (23) and bought a bike in January '24'. 2014 Yamaha Bolt. I've spent the last four months learning how to control the bike. Slow speed left and right turns. U- turns, twistys (as they are called), neighborhood traffic... kids, animals, golf carts and the occasional stop sign. I practiced emergency breaking.... locking up front and back tires trying to understand what it's like to not have ABS like a car/ truck has and to know what it's like to lay the bike down because of rider error...a mistake. (Dropping a bike sucks!!) Then on to the highway. Accelerating to 65 plus Mph. Merging into to faster traffic. The vibrating helmet, blurry mirrors and wind that reminds me that I'm supposed to trust the bike and my tires but also says never forget.... no walls, no airbags just you, your bike, your gear and what you know about 2 wheels. Daunting for sure. Controlling the bike at slow speed has been the biggest challenge. Cuz it seems the the bike does what it's supposed to do when it's moving faster that 10mph. But when it's moving slow....a different skill set.

I've dropped the bike 3 times since I bought it. Once during a slow planned u-turn, second at an intersection with a car that I didn't see and the third in a parking lot with thick gravel I didn't anticipate. I try to chalk it up to being a new rider. I spent $5k not $25k for that reason. Each time I dropped it, was an angry experience. Pissed cuz I dropped my bike, mad cuz I knew why and pushed forward like an angry new rider saying pick it up and go again.

April is here. I'm making left and right turns, in the neighborhood. Getting on the highway doing 70+. Making uturns. Merging into faster traffic with more comfort. When do I get to the part when I enjoy the ride??

Content:
Now that the Easter festivities are over, I'm DONE schlepping cages to and from repair appointments, and almost all of my farkles are here, I'm FINALLY working on getting them installed on the NINJA 400!


I had to start with a couple of simple things to give me a sense of accomplishment.


Note to self: Get one of these for the 650! Sheldon's is pretty worn from being dragged on the pavement so much when I move him around.. And these just look really cool!!

Then I pulled out "The Bible"...

...and looked up chapter and verse for how to remove the necessary Tupperware in order to install the frame sliders.


With the indispensable help of my father-in-law (He figured out how to remove the stupid fuse boxes), I got the left one installed before I had to go make supper.


After supper and evening outdoor chores, I installed the Denali SoundBomb Mini in the stock location (YES!!!!), followed by the swingarm spools.



Before cleaning up for the night so Bug could park in his spot, I took pictures of the bolts on the right side Tupperware before it's removed; otherwise, I might not remember which ones go where, once it's time to put it back on.

And I may have come up with a name...Gotta chew on it a little bit...

More to come!

Content:
Hello riders and mechanics.
To start off, I‚Äôll make it honest and simple. I love motorcycles and have had a few in my life time. But I‚Äôm not by any means an expert. I understand body mechanics for cars. Anyways, yada yada bla bla right? So above is a pic of what I would need to get info on. Firstly being a rider and not a mechanic, this is a CDI box? It doesn‚Äôt have any labels/model brand etc. I‚Äôm told that I need a new module, from my electrician (Spanish guy who doesn‚Äôt speak a word of English, and get around via his wife who translates) . He does general electrical work and doesn‚Äôt really specialize in bikes, though he‚Äôs good for it. He told me that ‚ÄúI had to get one of these‚Äù If you notice, my module or cdi box, whatever it is, has been scorched! I had flames under my butt, which I had to pull over and put them out. (Flames for paint work=üëç actual flames=üëé). This is for a 113 ci s&s motor. It‚Äôs not made on an assembly line, so there‚Äôs no way I can truly ever go shop at a Harley store. My question is 1)what is it? CDI? Do they catch fire often? it‚Äôs a six pin (actual screw driver looking heads and not flat). 2) where would a good place be to get these ? I see they apparently go for 900$ and as cheap as 12$, major difference in price clearly. Thank you for your help and happy riding

Vin

Content:
The Mercedes Brabus which is a Super Duke with different styling and no performance difference, is only $26,000.00 extra for the styling. The first release of 154 bikes, took a long, long time to sell....all of 2 minutes!


NEWS
Brabus 1400 R on Way
Another special-edition, Brabus-styled KTM Super Duke on the way.


By Ben Purvis
March 11, 2024


The Brabus and KTM collaboration continues with an upcoming trio of models similar to the 1300 R Masterpiece Edition seen here.Brabus
Brabus has been a name synonymous with modified Mercedes since the late ‚Äò70s but made the leap to two wheels with the Brabus 1300 R in 2022 and has found there‚Äôs plenty of customers prepared to pay high prices for a Brabus-branded bike. Now the company has filed three trademark applications for new Brabus 1400 R models‚Äîessentially confirming its collaboration with is set to extend with more ‚Äìbased bikes.

The was based on the , adopting its engine and chassis (unaltered) and wrapping them in distinct styling that included a round headlight borrowed from . The first generation was made in a limited run of 154 bikes (77 in red and 77 in black) to mark the company‚Äôs foundation in 1977. Despite a price equivalent to nearly $45,000 and no performance advantage over the $19,000 Super Duke Evo it was based on, all 154 were sold within two minutes of the order book opening.


The original Brabus 1300 R.Brabus
Unsurprising, then, that Brabus added a in 2023, the 1300 R Edition 23, with production increased to 290 examples. Again, these were split 50/50 between two colors, Superblack and Stealth Gray, and there were tweaks to the styling including a new headlight cowl and air intakes. Once again, they were snapped up fast, and Brabus launched the third version, , just a few months later. This was more exclusive with just 50 made, 25 in white and 25 in black, and Brabus promised it was the last in the line.


The latest Brabus is based on KTM‚Äôs new-for-2024 1390 Super
Now, of course, the is gone, replaced for 2024 by , so there‚Äôs scope for Brabus to do it all over again with a line of bikes using the updated 1,350cc engine from the new model. Complete with a shiftcam-style variable valve timing and lift system, the new motor puts out a claimed 190 hp at 10,000 rpm and 107 . at 8,000 rpm, up from 177 hp and 103 .


That engine, along with the latest Super Duke Evo‚Äôs chassis, suspension, and brakes, is sure to be the underpinnings of the new generation of Brabus bikes. The three trademark applications filed so far suggest that Brabus might be looking at the same idea as before, of offering three separate runs of bikes. The first trademark is for the name Brabus 1300 R Rocket. ‚ÄúRocket‚Äù is a title that Brabus already applies to some of its limited-edition, high-end Mercedes cars so it‚Äôs a logical way to connect the two- and four-wheeled output of the brand. We‚Äôve already seen with the and limited-edition bikes that there‚Äôs an appetite from collectors to buy bikes that match their high-end automobiles. But it‚Äôs not hard to imagine that , which already sells bikes using the name , might object to Brabus‚Äô plans to make a Rocket-branded motorcycle. We‚Äôll have to wait and see whether the trademark application gets approved.

The second trademark application is for the term ‚ÄúBrabus 1400 R Signature.‚Äù Again, Brabus already uses the term ‚ÄúSignature‚Äù on its existing output, but for its range of high-end boats rather than its cars. Nothing says you‚Äôve got money to spare more than an exotic boat, except perhaps having a matching motorcycle to go with it.

Finally, at least for the moment, there‚Äôs the trademark application for the title ‚ÄúBrabus 1400 Tailor Made.‚Äù The Tailor Made name digs back into the past for Brabus, as the company made a line of expensive, modified versions of the Smart ForTwo minicar under the same branding back in 2010.

Author: Benjamin_L

Content:
I really like my lowered, street-tired, geared-up Dr Zee for short knock-around trips. Still not loving it on the 70-mph artery that leads to just about anywhere from my town, but if I stay close to tiny town, or run the old road to the bigger town (18 miles primarily nice gravel road to Hamilton)

I really like Leo on the open road, and LOVE it on twisties. Considering adding some miles to my area of operation this summer with tank bag and small LEO tail box. Also considering trading it for a non-patrol version with side cases, BUT the super-low 15,000 miles on my fully sorted R1200RT with awesome near-new tires is compelling ... and the transaction cost of changing to a normal one with double, triple or quadruple the miles is intimidating.

I thought the vintage R90/6 would scratch the classic bike itch along with providing a nice intermediate bike between the other two, but it feels like a pig in comparison to either. I think 30-40 years of evolution spoiled me. I'm still working on sorting "the ultimate vintage" R90, but skeptical and, therefore, still scheming on "What do I really want?".

My current thinking is primarily to try the R90 again with some details like stiff throttle sorted out. Secondly, I see a couple of nice days coming up that I might spend looking at substitutes for the R90, or for it and Dr Zee.

At 74.5 years, weight is an issue ... Leo may have to give way to a bike under 450 pounds. I may be giving him up in the not-too-distant future ... oh, but I LOVE the cornering.

The Seca caught my eye when it came out - and still catches my imagination today.


I loved my '72 Brit ... the updates are always catching my eyes


Thanks to Peter Egan, I am now considering at least a Royal Enfield test ride

Title: New member
Author: spelunkerdog

Content:
Prior to today my wife had stuck to backroads, with the exception of a 6 mile stint in traffic.
Prior to two days ago it was not uncommon for her to go 5 MPH under the speed limit on straight roads.
Two days ago we rode to a park on backroads, which was a 28 mile round trip; she finally went the speed limit and I could see her confidence on the motorcycle growing. When we got home she said she wanted to ride the motorcycles to lunch on Friday; surprisingly, she picked a restaurant she likes a little distance from here.

Today was the day, 21 miles (45 minutes in traffic) one way to a restaurant by the water.
The weather was sunny and 70 degrees, perfect.
We had smoked fish dip appetizer and split a fried seafood platter, tasty.
The outing was fun and my wife's motorcycle riding & confidence continues to improve.

Title: Strange

Content:
I've been researching the best overall summer street Jacket and pant combination for impact and abrasion protection. years ago I ordered a Ultra 2 over pant from Motoport and found their construction and quality the best seen or rode in. Here I am years later and need a spring to fall riding gear and seem their aren't any other choices for Textile protection in the current market. Most garments are the best a poly or 500 Cordura stretch w/ not the best protection or ventilation. Their website hasn't been changed in years; their material and padding is thinner, but still 100% Kevlar. I visited their store in Southern CA, not impressed w/ collection, but was measured up, but when done in past found garment still needed alteration for proper fit and padding to be stiff. The other contender is the Rukka stretch air is probably 2nd best to most, not near as tout as Motoport, but still a stretch 500 Cordura w/ 700 in vulnerable places for abrasion. Motoport is a more a utilitarian design and Rukka and others have some style built in.

Title: Bike won't start without the fuel choke back
Author: PotHeadSteve

Content:
I am Roger Liston, I am a retired cycle engineer with Honda. I worked in their Torrance location after graduating from college with a degree in electrical engineering. While I went on to sell computer systems in silicon valley for 30 years, my hobby was fixing up cast off motorcycles. I revived a bike every 2 months for 30 years.
Now that I'm retired ,I specialize in fixing motorcycle electrical systems My website is expert cycle electrics. I am happy to answer questions by email or phone to help you sort out your problems online, if possible.

I also do unusual things like re-equip CB750s with digital gauges for their use on the salt flats, not to mention repairing older bikes that the dealers won't touch anymore. I love helping cyclists so send me a text describing your electrical problems. üòä

Content:
It seems strange to me that none of the mechanics who heard and saw the problem with the exhaust knew how to give a solution and also never encountered it.
What happened was that the original rivets came loose,
the ones that hold the black carbon end attached to the exhaust.

I improvisedly reinforced with some rivets, it held for a while and came loose again Like this about two or three times.
Of course this is caused by high vibrations
(the kind that also loosen screws in the license plate and distort it) And if so, then how is this not a common thing?


Have any of you ever seen one? Creative Ideas?

Content:
Hi all, newbie rider here (3 months in so far).

Have a couple of questions/observations and opinions needed here.

Live in Australia, on my L's, when u are on your learners plates, you must wear a fluro jacket (armless).. Coming from a road cycling background, I kind of don't mind it, I like being visible on the road, and let's face it my motorbike travels a hell of a lot faster than my bicycle. Equates to drivers having less time to notice me on the motorbike.

I'm on my L's for another month or so most likely, as have been riding a fair bit practising a lot of drills/skills and riding on all kinds of roads, so fingers crossed, pass it, then can take the fluro vest off. However, I'm thinking I am way more visible with it on, also have a white helmet, and ride with headlights on high during day. I really try to ride safely, and most importantly be seen, as In riding like I'm invisible out there to all other road users.

It doesn't look very cool or sharp with the vest on. Everyone here, esp the guys who ride cruisers/Harleys etc, ALL wear black everything, seems like people on sports bike/touring have a little more colour in their motorbike attire.. Is that normal in other countries?

Does anyone consistently wear fluro vests or other fluro gear out there?

On a side note I noticed a few bikes with an additional light, one that flashes, similar to what I use on my bicycle. Anyone have any thoughts on those.

Safety V Style... I kinda lead towards anything that will make me more visible, even if I end up looking like a newbie for the rest of my life.
Love your thoughts and opinions on this.
Andy
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
Motorcycle Training, Safety, and Riding Techniques
Title: Hi Viz or not? Do we want to be more visible out on the road or looking cool wearing all black?

Content:
Fraziers H-D had a demo ride day. I was in the last group of riders. I didn't have any particular model in mind to try, so I said to set me up with something "one step up" from the two other cruisers I've owned: A Harley Sportster 883 and a Honda Shadow 1100.

They put me on this 117 cubic inch low rider. And this thing is LOW. The seat's only something like 26" high.
It felt like I was straddling an 100 cc dirt bike.
But it was powerful. Quick. Smooth shifting on the 6- speed manual.
However, the "mid position foot controls" were still too cramped for me, given the seat height.
I think I'd prefer to have the seat 2" taller, and maybe THEN the controls would be in the right position to not have my hips and knees so bent all the time.

Oh, and the mirrors were too close to the bike's centerline. They need to be extended outward more, so I can see past my own shoulders.

The bike felt light, but according to the sticker on it, it weighs 680 lbs.
I would have guessed around 550! The center of gravity is low. And that really helps for stability.
Breadcrumbs:

Content:
I rode bicycles for years, did 3,000 miles on a bicycle one year.
I've put about 500 miles on my motorcycle and another ~200 on my wife's.
I see counter steering as a technique for motorcycle.
Pic from a thread that was closed:
I get (understand) the pressure against the tank, on right, how that helps turn.


I don't get why push the left handle bar to the right initially to go left, it is the opposite of the direction of the turn.
I know doing this thread will out me as a novice (or remove any doubt); so, yesterday when going to pick up pizza on motorcycle I try pushing the handlebar in the opposite direction of what I want to turn and I see how it corrects itself. Okay. I don't see (understand) the advantage of doing that.

I definitely have not been doing that on the motorcycle or bicycle.
I have not been pushing the handle bar in the opposite direction of the direction I want to turn; I had to think about it to do it.

I've watched videos on YT too and I don't get (understand) why or when the technique is used.

I'm driven motorcycles around town about 700 miles and apparently I've been doing it without counter steering because I had to think to do it and I don't get when the strategy is used.

I understand pressure against the gas tank.
Help me understand the when and/or why of counter steering because this novice doesn't get it and I'd like to eventually move beyond novice.
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
Motorcycle Training, Safety, and Riding Techniques

Content:
2002 Suzuki GSF 1200 Bandit

Problem:
Delayed power / lights when key is turned in ignition + will not try to start.

History:
Purchased bike February 2024 and it has been running like a top. No problems until 03/20/2024. I'm a newer rider so the bike has been ridden easy; short rides daily and some parking lot practice.

Problem Details:
We arrived home from a 20mi ride then decided to run into town to get gas. Bike was shut off for less than 5 minutes. Turned the key, lights came on as normal, hit the start, relay clicked and all lights immediately shut off / no power.

Currently it takes about 30 seconds after turning the key for lights to come on and dials to activate. Lights will stay on, but as soon as you hit start everything instantly dies. Relay clicks, but bike does not try to start.

Observations:
We haven't had the time to take anything apart yet, and are hoping to dig into it tomorrow. So far what we've looked at is...
Battery is 12.3V
Voltage is 12.3 from battery to relay (tried replacing 30 amp fuse, no change).

Has anyone had experience with this or know if this is a common issue with the ~2002 Bandit? Any suggestions welcome. Thanks.

Content:
So this came up recently after I was following someone riding, and I noticed almost every time they stop they seem to be struggling a bit because they pretty regularly didn't start putting their foot down until after the bike came to a stop. So I brought this up to them, as I would hope someone would do with me if they saw me doing something that clearly could be done more efficiently, and to my surprise they said if they tried to consciously control their foot when coming to a stop, it would mess them up.

This led to a whole discussion on the subject of conscious vs unconscious control, and it turned out both of us were somewhat amazed by the other's responses, because it seems like we are on far ends of the spectrum. They don't consciously control almost any of their physical movements, they think where they want to go and they go there, any body motions on the way are completely automatic, this includes walking, running, dancing, driving, and riding, etc. We got into a discussion about braking coming into a corner and they had no idea how they did it, they see the corner, think where they want to go, then somehow braking and steering happens.

This obviously works for them, but it completely blew me away because I am exactly the opposite, almost EVERYTHING physical I do is completely conscious. If I am very used to the activity, it doesnt take a lot of brain power, but I think about every single step I take when walking, running, dancing, driving, riding, swinging an axe or a hammer, etc. I learned how to drive on a stick decades ago and still each shift requires me to think about it, not a lot, but there is always a small process going that I am aware of going "ok, you are done with 3rd now, time to shift into 4th, or that hill is coming up so downshift into 2nd". Everything driving and riding is like this, I consciously steer a car, I consciously countersteer my motorcycle, I choose when to brake, how hard, and which brake to use every single time. This completely blew away the other person, we left this conversation with them confused about how I manage to do anything, and me confused about how they can possibly change anything they are doing, but both of our systems seem to work for us.

So it got me curious, how many function mostly on automatic for physical movements, and how many are mostly consciously choosing each step?
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
üèç General Motorcycle Discussion üèç
Title: Do your physical movements happen mostly automatically? Or are they mostly consciously chosen?
Author: Joel_The_Mole

Author: john.stock98

Content:
Hi I am looking for some advice on an issue which is quite strange.

I am currently working on a Lexmoto Assault 125 2020 plate. Its EFI. I was having some issues with the indicators not wanting to play ball unless the bike was leaned over or the steering was turned. After removing the fairings and headlight and checking all the cables, terminals and connections, they started to work as normal. However now the EML has come on the dash and the bike is a non start, it is ridden regulary nearly every day and dry stored in a garage overnight . In addition to this the battery is new as of a few weeks back when the old one that was in it when i bought it in November of last year had finally ran dry.

The strange part of this is with the EML on the bike appears to be priming the fuel pump, once when it turns on as it should but also now when the lights are switched from Dim to High beam and vice versa. To which I assume is causing an issue with the ECU and the EML and obviously the non start now.

Is there any advice that can be given on things to try to remedy this as I would rather not have to put it in a garage and then more than likely an autoelectrician as the money is not there right now.

Many thanks

Title: De-pin blue and orange 2pin connectors
Author: jamescarond02

Content:
Happy Spring everyone!!!
Yeah, I know it was yesterday but I was busy taking a little ride, 1023 miles of a ride, to be exact. This was not just a ride, but an Iron Butt Association SaddleSore 1000 , and it was one of 4 required for the 4 season rider Award, one on each Solstice and each Equinox. This one completes my set, and I applied and am waiting for the award.
I had started with the 'hard' one, the Winter solstice, then got the Summer and Fall but the 'easy' Spring one defied me, the weather is notoriously fickle this time of year, I was skunked twice and this year was no exception, we went from perfect warm weather Saturday to freezing rain on Sunday and the wild weather kept coming.
I was determined to get this certification this time though, I watched the weather, it looked good so I took off the day from work and went to bed, woke up at 0230 and looked at the radar...and saw SNOW all over. NOT AGAIN!!!
I was upset, aggravated, and annoyed, so I kept watching radar, trying to figure out the weather's track, googling webcams to see if it really was snowing, and it WAS!

I was ready to give up, but at 0745 something told me to just stop looking and ride, so I did. I think the sun rise helped a lot, it was soon above freezing and everything on the ground had melted! I rode right into rain, light snow, sleet, more rain, oh and don't forget WIND, 25 mph with huge gusts, the wind was relentless and brutal, but no ice, no slush, just water on the road all through PA, MD, WV, then it finally cleared up as I crossed into Virginia!
I rolled down the highway through Virginia to Marion, VA where my turnaround was going to be, great weather, my only issue was time, remember I had left 4 hours late, and I had to leave for work in the morning at 0430! Time was tight!
On the ride down I came up with an ingenious plan to save about 1.5 hours, I would short the ride some miles, turn back early and head to my house, stop and take a nap, then include my 62 mile ride to work as part of the ride, I was still well inside the 24 hour window and would end up with 1023 miles according to my calculations. I'll call this taking the REALLY long way to work

This worked perfectly, I got home ( riding again in drizzle and a few flakes of snow) at 23:58, slept 3 hours, headed to work, got my final gas receipt at the airport at 0600, and submitted my ride!
All 4 seasons achieved!
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
Motorcycle Stories

Title: Defective tires or bigger issues?
Author: Bbbikers

Content:
Thanks to anyone who cares to have a look! I'm just a little lost on what else needs to be done to my bike to get it running smoothly again.

I recently bought my bike and have had some electrical issues which I thought I had sorted but it's still feels strange. My headlight was flickering pretty badly and was quite dull, so I replaced it with a LED headlight just so i felt more comfortable - country roads around Devon at night are fairly sketchy.

On top of this, there was suggestion that there could be an issue with my regulator, so I replaced it. When that didn't solve the issue and my bike crapped out on me, I replaced the battery which did help with working semi-normally again. Most recently it seemed to be working perfectly until I was riding to work last night and noticed my heated-handlebar grips turned off by themselves again after about 15/20 mins of riding. They were already struggling to stay on before the new battery so this was puzzling as to why it started this issue again. I also noticed that it struggled to accelerate in every gear, however my suspicion is I need to change the oil and air filter (yay for more learning )

So I finally changed the alternator today, fresh oil and other tune up as necessary and noticed that my headlight is still flickering. Futhermore it struggles to stay on after turning on unless I give it plenty of revs/have the choke on.

Anyone have any suggestions on where to look next? For now I need to focus on the basic functionality and once I have some more money in my pocket I replace more parts if necessary (only recently returned to my home country and have pretty much no money)

Thanks again for any suggestions anyone has

Anyone ha

Hello, I‚Äôm hoping I might be able to get some help with questions I have regarding my v star im trying to fix up. It is seemingly having symptoms of running both lean and rich. I have cleaned my carbs, cleaned my air filter, checked all air/ fuel hoses for blockage, replaced fuel filter and spark plugs. To be noted I haven‚Äôt had my carbs synched yet. The bike runs okay, the power is there through all the gears at lower rpm‚Äôs but my acceleration cuts out and somewhat surges once I hit the top end of the gears. It is also backfiring during deceleration and sometimes having trouble coming down to the base idle. Choke on helps to start bike better but does not run well or better once warm. I‚Äôm wondering if I just need the carbs synched or if there‚Äôs something else troubling the engine. Any ideas or suggestions are greatly appreciated.

Thanks

Title: Questions about 05‚Äô v star 1100
Author: Marshdawg

Content:
Well, it's that time again! I put a new set of tires on my 2016 at the beginning of the season in 2020. I bought the 2016 new in 2018. I replaced the factory Dunlop's at just over 5000KM with a nice set of Avon Cobra Chromes. The factory Dunlop's were shot with the rear tread worn down and the front cupped. The recommended rear tire is a 240/40R18M/C 79V. I went with a 250/40R18 81V Avon since the 240 wasn't available at the time (COVID shortages). The 250 looks really good on the bike. I ride a lot of two-up and really liked the new tires. The front tire is still good and doesn't need to be replaced. The Avon's have just over 13000KM (8000 miles) on them. I'm not a fan of mixing brands and models between front and back tires so I'll probably go with another Avon since the front is still good.

I am however considering the Metzler Cruisetec model as a replacement. It looks like a decent tire. Has anyone used this tire on their bike?

Are there any other recommendations?

Thanks!

Content:
All other things being equal, does a parallel twin have any advantages or disadvantages compared to a V-twin of the same displacement?

All I can think of is a v-configuration can make for a slimmer bike,

but a parallel twin arrangement should be better for air-cooled engines because the windstream will hit both the left and right cylinder heads equally.

What other factors are in play here,

Things ive tried:

Using normal seat (makes crotch numb)

Carving the seat (can't carve straight)

Seatconcepts (causes sit bone pain that goes to my legs, and yes I gave time for it to break in)

Seatconcepts + Coleman maddog (same thing with sit bone pain but less)

Rubber mesh thingy (Good, but slightly numb)

And I'm already a cyclist (20 mile trips) and the reason my road bike seat is from a cruiser is because of sit bone issues.

My only guess right now is to maybe find a way to mount a rebel 250 seat onto it as I had no issue with that

So stock seat foam density is good but formed wrong + makes me sit too high despite being a tall rider

I am not in a position right now to spend $500 on a seat right now and I feel robbed with spending $350 on the seatconcepts (this was well before I knew they would take it back if two weeks didnt work)

Content:
Hello fellow riders, newbie here still working on technique, I was out practicing in the parking lot today working on slow speed maneuvers and for the life of me, this bike kept jerking at the slightest movement, I'm talking between 5 to 10 mph. I captured the recommended shift points on my phone for this Honda CB500f which shows the following in the owner's manual:

From 1st to 2nd (12 mph)
From 2nd to 3rd (19 mph)
From 3rd to 4th (25 mph)
From 4th to 5th (31 mph)
From 5th to 6th (37 mph)

I've watched various videos and read a number of articles that included: Throttle freeplay, (which I measured), throttle control (jerky motion), using rear brakes to illuminate jerking, etc.
I searched this form for related information but I haven't come across anything. Again, I was just trying to perform slow speed maneuvers at 8 mph and the bike kept jerking


Note: when shifting to higher shift points, no jerking motion, only during low speed maneuvers on flat surfaces.

Author: bweighmaster

Content:
So flipping through stuff on fork oil, it seems like almost the entire conversation is always about viscosity, which sure is important, but that is also like a 20 second sound blip: check the cst viscosity @40c and get the right one for your needs. Moving on.

When trying to find out other properties of fork oils, like what is their base oil made from? Mineral? Synthetic? How well do they act as lubricants? How long do they hold up? It seems like the entire field of fork oil is just pretty much an unregulated field full of snake oil, maybe even literally snake oil... Also, price and quality dont SEEM to have much overlap here, full synthetics and possibly something made from rendered roadkill seem to be within a few percentage of each other on cost.

So for the more experienced out there, what do you go by? Any brands that are known to lubricate better and hold up longer? Any guidelines? Or is it all just trial and error? Or should I just get a bucket of AeroShell fluid 31 for the lighterweight needs and use high quality synthetic engine oil for the hamfisted heavier stuff and call it a day?

Edit: After watching this video discussing how viscosity index and lubricity have a fairly inverse relationship, and knowing that fork oil is usually not much above ambient temp, fork oil marketing heavily emphasizing the importance of their high VI rating seems even more like a bunch of hokum, and that getting a good lubricating oil with good anti foaming properties and long term stability would be a lot more important than high viscosity index, at least for street bike forks:


Is there something I am missing here? Because the more I look into this the more I think I should just ignore "fork oil" for my street bike and just grab something like Mobil1 0W-8 which has a cst of 23 @40C or about what is commonly referred to as 5wt-7wt fork oil, or Mobil1 0W-16 which has a cst of 39.5 @40C or about what is commonly referred to as 7wt-10wt fork oil.
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
General Forums
üèç General Motorcycle Discussion üèç

Content:
I am 5'6" and naivley ordered Alpinestars Andes Drystar Pants in Medium SHORT, thinking that the waist is the same as their regular leg medium version, just with shorter legs. Wrong. So they are unsuitable for me (I usually wear pants with 32-33"stated waist, and 28-30" inseam).

Any recommendations for good riding pants in Medium, but with shorter legs, and otherwise the same pants as those with regular length legs?

P.S.: I prefer the non-jeans, non leggings type. I.e. heavy-duty waterproof pants with pockets and zippers.

JM

The upcoming eclipse was touched on a few times in another thread here at the Motorcycle Forum. Rather than jack that one, I figured it might be fun to have a thread dedicated to that particular subject. If the path wasn't so dang far from Big Sky Country, I might be tempted to use it as a road trip excuse, but that one is not going to make my wish list.

National Eclipse .com is a good website on the subject. I include one of their maps here, but there are several really nice ones there.
Check it out if the subject arouses your curiosity.

Also of interest is that people sharing a table of tea and biscuits at the tinfoil hat tea party are saying it will be a trigger day for major international, socio, politico, fasten-your-seatbelts events... giving those of us out of eclipse range something to watch for too.

Author: BADNESS

Content:
Hi everyone,

I'm excited to share something special that's been created just for us motorcyclists‚Äîby motorcyclists. Along with a team of fellow riders and designers, we've noticed a gap in the market: a dedicated space showcasing daily, hand-picked products for motorcycling enthusiasts. We're not a store; we're a curated collection where you can discover everything from the latest gear to bike accessories, books, gadgets, games, and even movies. If it's related to motorcycling and captures the essence of our passion, you'll find it here.

We're updating daily our selection with new finds, and we'd love for you to take a look.
LINK REMOVED

We hope you find something that excites you as much as it does us.

If you have a product you think it should feature on our blog, please share it.

Ride on!
Pedro Neta

Content: This year has been weird. I have been out riding several times this season, with the first ride of the year in early February. But here it is March 10th, and its back to winter cold. 26 degrees this morning, and only expected to reach about 40 today and for the next couple of days. But being an optimist, I am not throwing the covers over the bikes just yet. I do have them on Battery Tenders but I sure hope that I can ride again soon. Riding is about the only activity in my life where I am not acutely aware of my age. I'm 80, but as soon as I put my bike into gear and twist the throttle I feel like 40 years has slipped off me. I may be sore and stiff after an hour on the bike, but at least I have had that hour.

Content:
My 85 NH 650 had the stock jets, and because of a stumble just off of idle, I boought the complete kit from carbjet kits. I also cleaned the carbs.

Fast forward...

It runs great, but the fuel mileage is about 20-25 mpg. From what I've read it should be higher. This makes me wonder if I did the right thing. Perhaps the bike didn't need the kit, but the carbs just needed to be cleaned and the pilot jets adjusted. Plugs look normal, so I know it's not running too rich.

Anyone have the same experience as me? maybe reinstall the smaller main jet, or put the needle jet back to the stock position?

BTW, I haven't synced the carbs yet, (but I will tomorrow).
