Author: genel

Content:
It's a dark rainy day here in Bloomington, Indiana and my bike is in the shop getting the cam chest serviced. Sipping on some bourbon and trying to make good use of my time

With that, I'm curious. What is your favorite route ever? With no ego I can say we've ridden over 150,000 miles in the last 4 years while visiting every major scenic byway in the country. It's hard to narrow down a favorite, but Beartooth Pass may be it for me. Lots of curves, breathtaking views, wildlife, the list goes on. My first trip on this route actually got me a little emotional. It is absolutely gorgeous! Having a snowball fight in the middle of summer was also kinda neat.

Honorable mentions to the following: Million Dollar Highway, Going to the Sun Road, General's Highway.

All of my favorites in general are out west.

Title: Yukon/Alaska ride
Author: woodymcmartin007

Content:
The only light on the back of the Goldwing that I never converted
to LED was the license plate light. So I got an LED for that one.
Should be simple, right?
After nearly twisting my neck upside down with a flashlight,
I found that the license plate lens was held in with two tiny
phillips screws. Easy peasy!
The plate sits in a recess in the back of the fender with the light
above it. Turns out that there is no room to get a standard handle
screwdriver in there. Only a stubby would fit. And then....
Both of those screws were so effin' tight that I damned near mangled
the screws and my fingers trying to work in that tiny space.
Took forever to get them out...a small fraction of a turn at a time.
And THEN...the bulb does not push UP into the housing. The socket
is mounted sideways. You can't get normal human fingers in there
to grab the bulb. I ended up using TWO index fingers to grab it and
wiggle it back and forth a dozen times in order to
pull it out. And same kind of contortions to put the new bulb back in.
And of course the screws would not go in easily even though they are
just screwing into the plastic housing. I had to grease the screws with
Vaseline to get them to go back in.
What should have been a ten minute job ended up being nearly
an hour.
I wanna get a hold of the little Japanese guy who designed that
light housing and strangle him!

Title: Hi! New Rider here
Author: Rachel C

Content:
Hi all, I got a 2008 Hyosung Aquila GV250 about a month ago as my first bike and I've found the battery completely drained after a recent ride. I live in the city center so my rides are relatively short, stop-go, and I had never gone above 60kmph, but I've never had any issues with the battery draining until now. This past weekend I went on the motorway for the first time and then straight into a very windy and hilly route that ranged between 60-80kmph. I had my high beams on for the second half, but definitely had the lights switched off while stopped at my destination. On the way back, we pulled over and I found that I couldn't start the bike again (ignition switch did nothing, not even an attempt to roll over) and when I checked, the battery level checker I have installed was flashing red, despite having the charged the bike to full that morning. I have since charged it to full again and resumed my inner city driving with no issues.

The battery was replaced a little over a year ago, so I'm wondering if it may be the stator or R/R. Is it possible that the constant high beam was too much for the charging system to supply? Or that the more intensive roads heated up the plastic wire jackets causing a loose connection? I've picked up a multimeter and am planning on following electrosport's charging fault flowchart to investigate this weekend, but interested in other's thoughts.
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
Motorcycle Repair, Building, and Restoration
üîß Motorcycle Repair üîß

Title: Newbie here
Author: DannyParker

Content: I have this 2009 Suzuki GZ250, it didn't run or even turn over when i got her last month I had to rebuild the top end with new piston and cylinder head just so I could turn the engine over. I started checking electrical parts and needed a new ignition coil . Not to bad. Checked the pickup coil and stator and they checked out using multimeter . tried to start it and no spark . I pulled the ignitor and the manual has a chart to check the pins of the cdi. I was not getting any values on most of the pin combinations. So i started looking on Ebay etc. to find a new one but i was unpleasantly surprised to find how much$ they want for a sealed box with a few simple electronics inside. I took a chance on a 25$ new cdi for a 250cc Suzuki z something but although the plug would work the pin combination Measurment's (ohms) don't fit what the manual says. Now what to do.

Title: Noisy and jumpy clutch
Author: clodeperro

Content:
I sometimes practice to handle acceleration, on empty roads. I may roll at 22 mph (3k rpm, 2nd gear) press the clutch, slowly rev to 7-8 k rpm and drop the clutch. Not so much happens, the front wheel rises 1-2 inch (and I learn to handle that).

But if I rev up with a small, fast flick of the wrist and immediately drop the clutch, like the wheelie guys but w/ less power, my impression is the engine delivers much more power and one must be really careful.

Where does the power of a wheelie come from, if you quickly flick the wrist and drop the clutch?

One factor must be kinetic energy in the engine. The flywheel suddenly connects to the drive train. But are there more factors? Does a sudden quick flick of the throttle also "load the injectors with gas" and give this really strong power surge? I know too little about the throttle and injection system to tell.

Content:
Yesterday I was out for a nice 50 mile, one hour ride. I chose to take my CanAm Spyder because it was so windy with gusts at about 45 mph. With 3 wheels and about 1,000 pounds of weight, the Spyder does very well despite the strong cross winds, but I had to keep my helmet visor fully closed because open it felt like it might get snapped off in the high winds. Despite the bright sun and the high temps, not too many bikes were on the road, and those that were seemed to all be going quite slowly. I think I passed more two wheelers yesterday than I have on any recent ride. I assume that with 2 wheels the wind was having even more of an effect than it did for me on 3 wheels.

Another area where the Spyder seems less affected by wind than on regular motorcycles is when exposed to the wind blast of large trucks heading in the opposite direction on two lane roads. I always try to move as far to the right as is reasonable to try to offset the push of the wind blast, but with the Spyder do not feel a need to do anything. The passing trucks just do not bother me at all. In fairness I have to say that my new Royal Enfield Hunter 350 does not seem overly affected by passing trucks even though it is not a powerful bike, lightweight at 400 pounds and of course, has 2 wheels. I think that this is due to not having a windscreen. This is the first bike that I have owned in decades without a windscreen , and I think that this is why I am not feeling much of the wind blast from the trucks.

Content:
Most of the time I just feel like going for a ride. Just to have the experience of being out in the elements on my bike, even if it is just riding on very familiar roads for an hour and then returning home. But some days that doesn't seem like enough to motivate me to get the bike out of the garage. I feel like I need a destination.

When my wife rides as my passenger, we often go for lunch with a ride of an hour or two hours, then a leisurely lunch, then an hour or two hours ride home. That makes for an almost perfect day for me. But going for lunch has less appeal if I am riding alone. Sometimes I decide to run an unnecessary errand to a location a half hour or more away, just to have a destination to head to.

Motorcycling has been such a major factor in my life for so long that it sort of scares me to think about what I would do if at some point I am just not motivated to ride at all. But not today. Its supposed to be clear skies and about 75 degrees this afternoon, albeit with windy conditions, and even if I just stick to local roads I'm looking forward to getting out on one of my bikes.

Just a Sunday morning musing.

Content:
I picked up a neglected 85 XJ700 last fall. The factory Hitachi carbs are beyond repair. I thoroughly cleaned and attempted to rebuilt them by the book, But I believe they are too far gone. With the clean rebuilt stock carbs installed, new battery and fresh gas gravity feed from separate test tank, the bike cranks no start and every now and then a fire ball is visible at exhaust tip.
I have a pristine set of 4 Mikuni BSR32SS carbs off of a 98-06 Suzuki GSX600F Katana, that I would like to run on the XJ700.
The problem I have is the current intake boots do not line up with the Spacing of the Mikuni carbs.
I have been searching for different intake boots and I found a few that may work ( Kawasaki zx750 zephyr, Yamaha xj900f, Suzuki GS850 intake boots) based on 32mm carb side port, xj750 head port size , orientation (/ / \ \)and fastener hole spacing. The unknown variable that I am eyeing and guessing is the amount of offset needed the get the spacing correct. There is not a lot of technical info on intake boots making it difficult to choose a set that will work. I will post all the known center to center port spacing, carbs and head, as soon as I find my notes or remeasure. There has to be a more scientific, accurate way to figure this out aside from trial and error by firing the parts cannon at it with boots that look like they might fit.
I also considered keeping the stock boots and buying flexible adapters. This could work but the adapters would have to be very short because space is limited. If the carbs are situated an inch or 3 back due to adapters/spacer tubes, will that have any negative effects?
I am open to any suggestions . Thanks in advance.

Title: JohnD
Author: JohnD

Content:
Hello all!
I'm new to this forum, I recently purchased a couple of '89 Honda VTR 250 Interceptors for my wife. One is showroom condition with only 2563 original miles, the other is in Very Good condition with only 13,068 miles.
The first one looks like it just rolled off the showroom floor. The gentleman who owned it is an Irishman with little mechanical knowledge and he did an oil change himself, only problem is, he forgot to add new oil and locked this one up after riding it a couple miles...
The other is in really nice shape with more miles on it and more signs of wear and tear, but it has been well cared for and needed the carbs rebuilt and here is where the issue comes in...
The first bike I found all internal parts and pieces with all of the bolts and pistons with rods and rings, all of the timing chains and chain tensioners as well as an oil pump and pick up, the coolant piece that holds the thermostat as well as all kinds of electrical and mechanical bits to repair the seized engine.
The second bike, I did it to myself and I am not proud of what I did, but I did it and I will admit it... The carbs were gone through by me and I added fuel and allowed it to run for quite a while, brought the temp up to normal and thought it was all good. However after installing the fuel tank and adding about a half a gallon of fuel, the rear carb float was not right and I hydrolocked the engine...
I'm a mechanic for decades and was the shop forman in a Cadillac, Rolls Royce, Bentley dealership on the north shore of Chicago for years, I am also quite knowledgeable about Honda and Kawasaki road bikes, I was an Iron Butt rider and did 1000 mile days for years...
So, I pulled the plug and spun the engine over and fuel squirted out, but I thought it needs to spit more out and when I did the second spin over the dang thing blew more fuel out and you know what happened then...
So, now I am repairing and replacing anything that had fire damage, which in the grand sceme of things is VERY little. But I need the petcock knob which got a little melted and I have already found a seat cover and wiring harness bits which were slightly melted, but I learned my lesson... I cannot believe that I did that!
I have a 1975 Honda CB 750 F Super Sport that has only 8218 miles on it from new. It has sat outside in the desert for a while, but the wiring, seat and other stuff still looks new, he was smart enough to remove a bunch of stuff and then it just sat, I have to finish rebuilding the carbs on that bike, but I was more into getting my wife's VTR running...
I'm gonna need some pieces and parts and hope that someone on here can help with getting the bits I need...
Thanks, sorry I am long winded and had to tell all from the getgo!
dmkberger

Content:
I could come up with probably a bike for every company. Since it's not my money no risk. I imagine other people who are into bikes could do the same.

So here is an idea for a bike .
A big like a thousand cc push rod single from Harley. With belt drive and self adjusting valves. Without the air cooled sportster they don't offer a budget bike. They sell twins over 2000 cc now . Unlike the Buell blast they could counter balance it. Harley has excellent vibration control with rubber mounting their engines. Harley has a history with singles.
A single is easier to hit emissions standards with. KTM and Ducati have near 700 cc singles that produce mid 70hp. While being pretty much vibe free. So a lower revving bigger single is possible. Maybe 60-65 hp. Make it 500 lbs and you have a solid bike.

Title: Motor cycle cut off and now has no electrical power
Author: Bagel

Content:
I don't want to go too far down the EMP (electro-magnetic-pulse) rabbit hole with this thread, but hope to ferret out what electronic components I (we) would need to restore function to our motorcycles were an EMP to strike them dead.

The smaller the space between circuit traces, wires or electron paths, the more vulnerable the parts are. Said another way, newer tech, more modern stuff, more sophisticated electronics take less EMP energy than older, clunkier, cruder electronic pathways. Thus Missy's 1978 Honda XL75 (Piglet) is less sensitive than my 2011 BMW F650GS (Jack).

Nevertheless, I am wanting to get electrical part spares for Piglet as well as Jack ... not to mention my non-bike power plants.

With my automobiles, I have local mechanics I think I can trust with the task of prescribing, ordering, supplying and, if necessary, installing the necessary parts. With the bikes, I do not have those resources. Thus I am interested in information I might get from YOU here on this forum.



On a related subject, how do I install these things if I have to do it myself?

------

By the way, I go into more detail, background over here:

Content:
Hi all, new to CBRs and the forums. I recently bought a 1988 Honda Hurricane 600 and and am trying to diagnose an issue I am having with the front brakes. I originally rode the bike back 250 miles with no issues, only to struggle here in town with my brakes seeming to heat lock. It only takes a few blocks for them to start self applying and getting very hot.

As I did not struggle with this issue on the way home, that makes me believe that it is not the brake lever, and that it is properly adjusted. I did find a seized piston in the front right caliper, replaced it, and am still having this issue. After R&R the caliper, I took it out to test and the same issue occurred. The fluid is obviously over pressurized, as when I cracked the bleeder screw, it shot fluid out. The caliper is very hard to compress, and I am unable to do it by hand. To me (very green to bikes so would love some help), that leaves two possible causes:

A) The compensating port in my master cylinder is bad and not allowing fluid to return to the reservoir to reduce pressure while fluid expands from getting hot.
B) My brake line is splintering internally and acting as a check valve, allowing fluid to run towards the caliper but not back

Before I order parts, is there a way I could test to see if it was either of those, and if not, which one would you all think most likely to be the culprit here?

Content:
https://www.motorcycleforum.com/threads/different-kind-of-motorcycle-mishap.253304/#post-2761794

Sparkman ended up in the hospital when his motorcycle fell off the ramp when he was trying to load it in the bed of a pick up truck.

I have used ramps to load a small motorcycle -- a dirtbike that weighed less than 300 pounds-- into a pickup truck before, and that was do-able with two people. I could never do it alone ", but with two people we would push the bike up the ramp while we stood on the ground next to it, and then once it was in the bed one person would hold it steady (prevent it from rolling back out) while the other person climbed into the bed and pulled it in the rest of the way.

Clearly, what I did with that Yamaha 250 dirtbike or the Honda 125 before it would not work for a real motorcycle that weighs 450 to 750 pounds.

I did Use my brothers four-wheel-drive pickup truck, to load my Honda Shadow 1100 (600 lb. cruiser) one time. The bike was able to start & run briefly. We backed his truck down to a spot in the front yard so the rear wheels fell into a ditch. That made his tailgate only a few inches higher than the grass. A scrap piece of plywood helped my wheel climb that slight little gain of elevation and I rode the bike into the truck bed. But, if his truck had been 2WD it may not have been able to pull itself out of the ditch.

Oh, one other time my Harley Davidson Sportster 883 (a 500 lb. cruiser) broke down near a church. My brother came to get it using only his pickup truck and not the landscaping trailer I hoped he would bring.

The bike was not running but I did manage to push it up a wheelchair ramp to the top of the stairs at the church's main entrance. My brother backed the truck up to the staircase and when we lowered the tailgate it lined up perfectly with one of the stone steps. So I straddled the bike, sitting on it, rolled it down the steps for about 4 feet of steep downhill rolling before it bounced into the bed.


Let's talk about safe & effective techniques to load a decent sized motorcycle into a pickup truck's bed.

Assume that we're talking about a normal tailgate height for a full sized pickup.
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
Motorcycle Repair, Building, and Restoration
How To
Title: How to use Pickup Bed to Transport
Author: gunsmoker

Content:
I'm Adrian Cash owner of Northside Motorcycle Tyres and Service. In Lawnton, Brisbane Australia. I just wanted share my passion, to create a Motorcycle repair shop that caters for all makes and models, with a strong focus on providing exceptional customer service and value for money.
I am a BMW and Harley-Davidson factory trained technician with over 26 years in the industry and I specialize in motorcycle diagnostics, tyre recommendations and getting your ride running like a dream. On the weekends I spend my time with customers and friends out and about on my bike.

I have a team of staff both on the tools and behind the counter. We specialize in all major motorcycle brands including Harley-Davidson, Triumph, BMW, Honda, Suzuki, Kawasaki, Yamaha, KTM, Husqvarna. From a minor oil change and routine inspection to a major service or rebuild, our qualified motorcycle technicians have over 40 years experience in our modern workshop equipped with all the latest diagnostic equipment to maintain your motorcycle to the highest standard. We have a wide range of Spare Parts and genuine and aftermarket in store and online.

Content:
I don't want to go too far down the EMP (electro-magnetic-pulse) rabbit hole with this thread, but hope to ferret out what electronic components I (we) would need to restore function to our motorcycles were an EMP to strike them dead.

The smaller the space between circuit traces, wires or electron paths, the more vulnerable the parts are. Said another way, newer tech, more modern stuff, more sophisticated electronics take less EMP energy than older, clunkier, cruder electronic pathways. Thus Missy's 1978 Honda XL75 (Piglet) is less sensitive than my 2011 BMW F650GS (Jack).

Nevertheless, I am wanting to get electrical part spares for Piglet as well as Jack ... not to mention my non-bike power plants.

With my automobiles, I have local mechanics I think I can trust with the task of prescribing, ordering, supplying and, if necessary, installing the necessary parts. With the bikes, I do not have those resources. Thus I am interested in information I might get from YOU here on this forum.



On a related subject, how do I install these things if I have to do it myself?

------

By the way, I go into more detail, background over here:

Title: Hello everyone
Author: Jackman

Content:
Hey there,
Don't get mad from the title for a start

I am currently living in Greece and I ride a Honda Steed 400, which I bought for 2k, Harleys here go for around 6-7k for a nice sportster.

I am having a debate with myself considering whether I should upgrade my Honda Steed and spend around 1 to 1.5k maximum, to change the engine and make it look better as well, or just be a bit patient and get a Harley which is a dream of mine.

Harley pros and cons:
It's a Harley
I will be able to cruise much more comfortably since my Steed is going at 120/130 klm per hour tops, which is frustrating when I ride on open roads
I will have to spend more money to maintain it, but my question here is how much more...
I will be a bit stressed every time I take it off to work and stuff since in Greece they tend to steal a lot (usually though they don't mess with Harleys, but overall you never leave your motorcycle out of sight here)
Riding into town for work etc won't be the most comfortable thing since the streets and traffic here are pretty bad

Honda Steed
It feels better to ride it into town and leave it unattended sometimes since I am not afraid that someone is going to mess with it, also it feels a lot better to drive through traffic without worrying that something will happen to it, In general, I don't worry about anything since it's not such expensive in a way...
It is uncomfortable to drive into big highways since I feel it has no power... I do a 100klm trip and I feel like it's about to explode even if I stop like 2 times to give it a rest.
I suppose that fixing it is also cheaper

My current state is that I live in Greece as I mentioned and let's say I make 1k per month... Considering that I buy the Harley, will I be able to maintain it?
Also from what I hear, Harleys tend to "break" more often than a honda steed, I don't know whether that's true or not, but I don't have the comfort of staying without my bike for more than a day (let's say I have to leave it to the mechanic or whatever)
Also, I would like to note that I don't care about the weather, I ride even if it is pouring rain like hell... (Although if I get the Harley I think that I will stop doing that, which will be a hustle for me..
Finally, I am talking about a used Sportster from the 1990s, yes that costs from 6k to sometimes even 12-13.

I understand that reading this can be very frustrating for you Harley Riders, but I want to consider everything since I will have to spend all of my savings doing a move like that... I am 23 years old so no family to take care of etc, it feels like the best time to make a move like this

Title: Harley or a Custom Honda Steed
Author: GeorgeX0006

Content: I have a Kawasaki KZ440 LTD. I've been losing spark when riding causing me to go to the side of the road and struggle to get the bike to start again. I took off the tank and checked all wiring and found nothing suspicious. I replaced the coli, igniter and pickup coil and still the bike quits at random. Might be 50 feet or 5 miles before it quits. Yesterday in my garage I tried to start the bike but it wouldn't start. Not a peep out of it but it ran the day before. I checked my spark plug wires with my meter. I found one of the wires was dead or open...no reading with the meter. I checked further and found that the plug cap was open. Should have had 5k ohms with it as it's a resistor cap. I used a spark tester on the other cylinder and had no spark there. I thought the bike could start on one cylinder. I purchased a new cap and installed it and the bike started immediately and idles good. Haven't taken it out for a ride to test it yet due to the weather. My question....Would that bad cap kill the spark on the other cylinder? Had no spark on the second cylinder until I replaced the cap on the first cylinder. The coil is one that has the two leads going to it causing the plugs to fire at the same time. My question.....Do both plugs have to have a ground in order for the bike to run? I thought I read somewhere where they do but I can't find it. Thanks for your thoughts guys, Collieman

Content:
Yesterday I read a news article about Ann Margaret still riding her Harley at 82 (Ann, not the Harley). I think that's great, and she was also great in my eyes (especially because of her commitment to those of us in the military) but I don't really think it is that remarkable that she is still riding. I'm almost 81 and ride and hope to be doing so for many more years. After my ride yesterday I stopped to fill up the 3 gallon gas tank on my new Royal Enfield Hunter 350 when a older gentleman in motorcycle clothing came around the gas pump to look at my bike. He assumed it was an old vintage British bike when he saw the RE logo, and seemed surprised when I told him that it is now an Indian company and that the bike was brand new. Since he looked even older than me I had to ask him how old he is and what was he riding. He was on a 2023 Harley cruiser (pretty bike, for sure) and told me that he is 86! I told him that he's my new hero, and wished him a safe ride.

Maybe years ago there weren't so many older riders. I have met many who told me that they had been riders but had given it up due to age and physical issues, and often the person saying this was much, much younger than I am. Maybe its the result of modern medicine that people my age can still comfortably ride motorcycles even if they, like me, gave up a really heavy bike and went to something lighter.

So I still like Ann Margaret, and I'm glad she's riding, but I don't think its really that special.

Content:
Hey All,

I wasn't going to post this, but I got bored and decided what the hell. Yesterday we had record high temps and I was going to take my lil dualsport out for a ride in the woods. As I was pushing it up a ramp into my pickup bed, I took a step back and fell onto my driveway. The bike rolled out too. I ended up with an open dislocation of my left elbow and had to have the wife take me to the ER where it was surgically repaired. I'm typing this from the hospital right now. The doctors estimate a 3 month recovery. The first thing I asked was "is the bike ok?" and "how soon can I ride again?" The wife was not amused . I'm posting this as a cautionary note and am wondering if anyone else has dislocated their elbow and if so, how long it took to ride again? Let's be careful out there and no, I won't be posting any pics. Too gory.

Anytime i try and start it it either doesn't start at all and just clicks or will turn over and idle for a few seconds then die again, spraying starter fluid in the airbox makes it turn over more often but it will still die after a few seconds even with the choke fully on. so far I've tested the spark which is working fine and I've fully rebuilt the carbs which were weirdly clean for sitting for god knows how long. I've also had to change the gas tank out for a leak but i doubt that would change anything, there is gas getting all the way down to the carbs and filling them.

üå∑ Springtime Splendor: Witness Amsterdam in full bloom as we glide along its picturesque canals and charming cobblestone streets.
The air is filled with the sweet scent of blossoming tulips, creating a magical atmosphere you won't soon forget.

üè∞ Discover Hidden Treasures: From historic bridges to quaint cafes tucked away in alleyways, we uncover the city's best-kept secrets and soak in its rich culture and history.
Every twist and turn reveals a new delight, making each moment of this journey truly unforgettable.

üéµ Serenade of the Streets: Feel the rhythm of the city as we navigate its bustling avenues, with the gentle hum of my motorcycle harmonizing with the sounds of Amsterdam.
It's a symphony of sights and sounds that will transport you to another world.

üì∏ Breathtaking Views: Get ready for breathtaking vistas as we climb to vantage points offering panoramic views of Amsterdam's skyline. Whether it's the majestic spires of historic buildings or the glistening waters of the Amstel River, every sight is a feast for the eyes.

Title: Custom Paint
Author: Steadfastly

Content:
Hi, I'm Mike, currently living in Fullerton, CA. I am married and have a son and daughter. I met my wife while living in Hawaii, where I attended the University of Hawaii at Manoa and surfed a lot. Although I have been riding since I was 15, I stopped after I crashed into a car that turned left in front of me. Not because I no longer wanted to ride, but because I couldn't find and/or afford the parts to fix my Norton 850 Commando.

2 yrs ago, at age 68, inheritance funds allowed me to start riding again. I started with two HD Sportsters, a 2006 Sportster XL1200L Low and a 2009 XR1200. Last summer I added a 2010 HD Dyna Super Glide. Recently, I got a 1981 Suzuki GS250T for the purpose of using it to pass the skills portion of the California motorcycle test, which is really a low-speed maneuverability test, difficult to pass on a large bike. If you're interested and can tolerate my long-windedness, I have a much longer description on my profile.

Since I'm old now, I find my riding style has changed from my younger aggro days, which I somehow survived. Now, as a guy on one of my other forums puts it, "I ride like an old guy, who wants to get older."
Breadcrumbs:

Title: Hello riders üí™
Author: Enzo rider

Content:
Hello everyone, first time bike owner here, and I just purchased a 2008 Suzuki GSX650F. It needs new fairings and the previous owner did some unorthodox wiring when installing custom LED lights (which have been removed before purchase) but mechanically it functions beautifully. Or it did at least.

I was aware when I bought it that it would need an oil change. My friend helped me drive it from the seller to my place (about 90 miles) and he had no issues, said it ran beautifully and wishes he could ride it more. I then put about another 20-30 practicing while waiting on my paycheck to get the new oil and filter. It ran perfect.

I got 4 quarts of Lucas 10w40 Synthetic Motorcycle Oil and a K&M filter designed for this bike. I went home, drained the old oil, and removed the filter. After letting it all drip out, I put in 3.5 quarts (online says 3.7 is capacity but I've also read putting a tiny bit less is safer then putting a tiny bit more so I leaned on the lower side. The oil is just below the F line) all after filling the oil filter about halfway and installing that. Cleaned up the bike, turned it on and it started right up. Let it run about 10 minutes then got on and took it for about 2 miles away, turned around, and about 1.8 miles back the engine stalled. Turned right back on, got it home, did some quick runs around my house and it was fine.

Next morning I turned it on, no issue, pulled in the clutch and shifted into first and the bike leaped forward and stalled. Tried again, same result. Tried again from first gear, the starter pushed the bike forward but didn't start. Like the clutch isn't disengaging. The digital gear indicator will go 1,N,2 but if I try to shift to 3 (with the bike off) the screen blanks and it doesn't sound like it's shifting properly. I also noticed once the bike warmed up that it was bogging a bit when in idle, and if I revved to anything above 5k and let off the throttle it stalled about half of the time.

I redid the entire oil change with new oil AND filter and nothing. I even brought it to the F line and still have the issue. It's got a hydraulic clutch so I can't even seem to find help on how to adjust it, as I have read that it is common after a oil change to need to do that. Honestly I can't find anything about this bike except a few botched videos in YouTube.

I would appreciate any advice or help anyone may be able to provide. This has me very irritated and is leaving me with a sour taste, but I know it is fixable so in trying to keep a clear head. Thank you all!
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums
üèç Motorcycle Forums üèç
Sportsbike Forum
Title: GSX650F shifting stuck after oil change, help?
Author: RyanM8640

Content: Hello, I just joined the forum. I recently bought a 1981 Suzuki GS250T with 2458 miles on it. Although it has low miles, time has taken a toll, especially to the rubber and aluminum parts. Someone in the past even welded patches on the exhaust pipes where condensation probably ate holes in them, but they didn't smooth out the welds. All the lights and signals work though, so we settled on a reasonable price. I trailered it home because, although the seller put a new front tire on it two weeks before I bought it, the rear tire has cracks all around the sidewall. Finding a 3.50 x 17 tire was a challenge, but Duro still makes one, which I've ordered. The seller bought the bike 20 years ago to teach his wife, but that never happened, so it mostly sat, and he only rode it occasionally. The seller said he flushed out the fuel tank and cleaned the carbs last summer, and the gas in the tank is from then. He never changed the spark plugs, so they're 20+ years old. It will start, but it is very cold blooded and even warm it will not idle without the choke. It will rev if the throttle is slowly rolled on but will bog with faster throttle applications. Obviously, I will drain the fuel and replace it with fresh and change the plugs. Beyond that, I feel the carbs are the problem. They are Mikuni BS30 SS. I have not been able to locate a rebuild kit for them yet. Any thoughts? Thanks in advance.

Content: Hello. Due to the needs of the technical inspection in my country I had to replace the turn signal with a turn signal with European markings. I replaced it and I did not like the frequency of blinking and also I noticed that it flows twice. On the seller's page it says about a relay with a regulator I ordered it I put it on and it's better, I can adjust the frequency as I need. But the double flows are still there. The polarity is correct, the relay is correct, the only thing I suspect is the resistors. Maybe someone has encountered such a thing and can give some advice. I would like to note that before replacing the relay and turn signals, there was no such thing. Maybe it's not the motorcycle system itself, but the turn signals themselves?

Content:
Hello everyone,

I bought my motorcycle a few months ago probably in June 2023 and it has never truly idled properly. I stalls on me quite frequently. I don‚Äôt ride it a lot for this reason, but I am not sure how to fix it and make it idle smoothly.
I recently pulled out the carburetor and cleaned the jets, I added new spark plugs cause those went bad as well and I got a new battery installed. I can start the bike and when I have the choke all the way out it‚Äôll idle just fine. If I put the choke back in, it dies on me, unless I‚Äôm pulling the throttle. I can ride it just fine usually, but anytime I come to a stop or near stop it dies. So now it dies anytime I‚Äôm standing still on it.
Has anyone had these issues before? Should I mess with the idling PMS screws? I would do this, but they are capped off and this makes me believe the manufacturer doesn‚Äôt want them to be accessed. Should I clean the carburetor again?
Another interesting thing I found is that the throttle cable screw was all the way loose and held in place by a zip tie‚Ä¶ not sure what that was about but hopefully it gives some extra info.
Anything helps, I just want to get it running smoothly hopefully.

Title: My honda Cbr929 won't start. (Wire problem)
Author: Jermaine

Content:
This thing is geared ridiculously low. About 75 mph or so at 4,000 rpm. Redline starts around 10. Taking off in 2-3 on this thing is about the same as taking off in first on my 600 GSXR. I'm a curious guy. WHY ? Is it emissions to keep the breadbox cat hot ? Is it to make the bike feel more nimble around town ? It's a technological marvel but kind of silly in some ways. Why would a sport cruiser with the emphasis on sport be geared like that ? And the gearbox is closely spaced. In some gears I'm only dropping around 500 rpm's. It deff tends to make me go slower. That's a good thing. You hammer it you better be ready to shift. It winds out quick. Not really complaining, I'll change sprockets. Some have added two teeth up front AND taken one or two off the back. That's gonna help greatly on take off, and at highway cruising, but in between those two points it'll feel the same.

With the key on and the bike not started it makes a very quiet beeping noise. You'd never hear it with the bike on. Thought it was pretty cool. I get on the Ninja forumes...Nope. No One Nothing. One guy says it sounds like it might be an apple air-pod. I google the sounds they make, yep, it's an air-pod being powered up. (must be hard wired to the ignition) Text the previous owner, yep. Says he sticks them on everything and forgot about it. I wonder. Guy seems like he has way better things to do than track my bike. but who knows. I said I'd mail it back to him once I got it off.....

Content:
The starter on my '82 Sportster worked perfectly yesterday. Today I turned on the ignition, everything lit up, the battery was fully charged, but when I depressed the start button the starter didn't work at all, or even make a clicking noise. I noticed a noise under the seat, so I took the seat off and found that the starter relay was making noise and vibrating every time I depressed the start button.
The relay is the original one from '82. I ordered a new one. I know nothing about electronics. Does it sound like the relay is bad? I hope that's the case. It's an inexpensive part.
Thanks!

Content:
Hi all,

I am installing some new indicators on my 2000 Honda VTR250. These indicators have a sequential turn on style which given constant power will cycle on and off, because of this I'm keen to bypass the flasher relay such that when I turn my indicator on it provides constant 12V as opposed to the normal on off sequence.

I thought I might just be able to jumper between what I thought was the 12V positive and load pin and leave the earth pin empty but when I tried this, it just turned all the blinkers on when indicating either way. I haven't been able to decipher exactly what the 3 pins are other than the earth nor have I been able to find a usable wiring diagram, that being said I would think it may be similar to similar Honda year models.

Here is a photo of the relay, any ideas would be appreciated.
Thanks

Title: 05 yamaha ttr 230 revive
Author: caldwellbilly3

Content:
Here's where it leaks.



I tried taking the petcock off, but the 8mm bolts spin and spin and don't come out. New tanks are easy to find but are $175. Seems like a lot for what is probably a problem with the 0-ring seal. Relevant pics from site selling new tanks:

1. Looks like the two bolts don't go all the way thru to the inside of the tank. The nuts must be turning in the plastic. Have seen this problem with lawn mowers as well. Bad design.



2. The petcock with no gasket which surprised me:



3. Misc related parts:



Betcha the issue is the O-ring. The two parts on the right must be spacers for the bolts at the petcock.

I'm fixing this bike for the neighbor boy who received it from his uncle before he passed away. It means a lot to this kid. I'd like to help him and will involve him all the way through the repairs as there are many others. But first, we've got to get the tank to stop leaking. It does run, but idles kind of high. Initial list of issues:

1. Tank leaks.
2. Runs but idles high.
3. Right side foot peg missing.
4. Rear brake lever and rod are missing and no where to be found.
5. Front brake cable locked up solid (kid tried to replace cable).
6. Clutch is very tight at the lever. I can hardly pull it in.

The young man has a job and is willing to pay for parts. I might try hacksawing those old bolt heads off before suggesting we buy a new tank.

Thoughts?

Content:
Hi everybody. I grew up on a farm and my dad bought us a Honda 90 which we used and abused heavily. Then I graduated to an Ossa 250 motocross bike that I tried to jump the drainage ditch with and did not make it to the other side. I went over the handlebars and bruised the front of my legs so heavily I could not walk the next morning. I'll never forget my dad laughing as I crawled up the steps for breakfast the next day.

My brother raced flat trackers at the Sycamore Speedway in IL in the 70s. So, our family has had a few bikes through the years.

I'm here now to help the neighbor boy with a Honda XR100 he got from his uncle before he passed away. There are a lot of problems with this bike, but I've done a lot of small engine repairs and hope to get some help from the repairs section of this forum.

Also did some repairs on a Kawasaki my son and I picked up for cheap after the owner plugged the oil pathway with gasket sealer and wrecked the valve cam and head. Fixed it and sold it. I think it was a KM100.




Good to be here.

Content:
FZ6R overheating and low coolant light
I have a 2009 Yamaha FZ6R and I‚Äôve recently encountered a problem with overheating. The low coolant light came on while i was on my way home from University and the temps went over normal operating conditions, so I changed the coolant and bled out all the air but the issue persisted. I checked the water pump and it was working when I turned on the bike. I was told maybe it was a head gasket issue, but a car mechanic friend told me the coolant would be either mixing into my oil or smoke would be coming form the engine and I checked oil and it was fine, also no smoke was ever coming from the bike. I ended up changing the thermostat and it didn't fix the problem. I checked fans and they kick in around 200 degrees F. The old coolant looked good. The radiator has no cracks and none of the hoses are leaking coolant. At this point I'm lost on what to do.

Title: FZ6R overheating issue
Author: Ascension

Content:
About three weeks ago I go to local motorcycle dealer to look at new 2023 CFMOTO 300SS advertised for $3,000 and I had yet to be "educated" to motorcycle dealer fees.
I know I have to pay sales tax, title, tag, probably some assembly and destination fees. Tax, title, and tag is ~ $400 actual cost, that I know; I figure maybe another $600 in "fees" so the motorcycle should be about $4,000 total, right? Wrong!!! They wanted $5,000 out the door with no extra warranty, just tax, title, tag, fees. A motorcycle advertised for $3,000 becomes $5,000 total which was quite a shock to the uninitiated.
(Dealer adds fees to used bikes too).

I decide to look for used motorcycles from individual sellers on Facebook marketplace.
2021 Honda CBR300 with 4k miles, one owner - I have about 5k in it after tax, title, tag and a new rear tire.
2021 Yamaha YZF R3 with 135 miles, one owner (it sat unused since 2021, they recently had fuel lines cleaned, oil changed ect... got it to running order and it runs great, I've put 100+ miles on it this week) I have just under 5K in it after tax, title, tag.

(FL tax, title, tag was $416 & $430 on these and is based on reported sales price.)






I have no plans to sell either, but IMO if I had to sell I'd probably lose less money on either of these than if I had bought a new 2023 CFMOTO 300SS for the same 5k that I have in each of these.

I also think dealers should advertise the "fixed" fees they charge so potential customers are not blindsided when they go to a dealer to look at motorcycles. On their website they could say our sale price only is 3k and your total out the door price is "only" 5k. some dealers do that.
Breadcrumbs:

Title: Hey Riders
Author: luongomike405

Content:
Did you ever try to make your own windshield?
Well, a few months back, I decided to try.
Now, I've made windshields before, and for most bikes, it's not too difficult, since they are basically flat.
But the Goldwing 1500's shield is not so easy.
This project has been giving me agita for months. The 1500's windshield is a complex shape with a compound curve to it, plus it has five mounting slots near the bottom which engage the adjusters that let you move the shield up or down. Making one out of a flat sheet of Lexan was a pain in the....well, you know where.
I finally finished it today and got it mounted!!! Yee ha!

The original windshield had become foggy and scratched over the years. So last year I bought a replacement from some aftermarket dealer. It was a nice windshield, (aside from costing a small fortune) but it was too thick, so the adjustment mechanism no longer worked right. There was no way I could move it up or down. Plus, the compound curve was even more exaggerated than the original, which warped the view and gave me a headache when looking at things close in front of me, like the white line on the road, or Jersey potholes!
So I set about making my own from a flat sheet of Lexan from Amazon. I started and stopped on this project several times over the last few months, trying to figure out how to trace that odd compound shape onto a flat sheet of Lexan, and how to cut those five mounting slots so the adjuster would work.
Finally, this morning it all came together. It was was a pain but worth it. And it only cost a fraction of what a aftermarket shield costs. I think I paid $46 for a sheet of eighth inch thick Lexan from Amazon.
The aftermarket shield that I bought last year cost around $200!!
So I'm a happy man. I now have a flat windshield that doesn't distort the view ahead.

Content:
Does anyone have a review of the above tires ? Or a comment from a mate who runs them ?
I have read some very good reviews but not many first hand user comments.
My mate has them(M R 6's) on his SV650 and has mentioned that they are the bomb .This guy has spent years modifying suspension on his little SV650 making it the best handling SV650 it can be but the biggest difference he said is the bike now with the Michelin Road 6's. He rides with the super fast crowd too on out local range , it's mostly tight 3 and 4th gear corners so a modified SV650 is quite competitive . A tad underpowered going up but super fast under brakes coming down the range .
The Michelin Road 5 developed cult status among the Super Sport and Cruiser clans using them.
I have used the 5's and they stuck like glue , so when all reports are saying the 6's are a much better tire than the 5's , I'm looking into it.
They're expensive but they just might be worth it.
ONLY MICHELIN ROAD 6 REPLIES PLEASE !
Cheers .

Title: From what I've heard...
Author: genel

Content:
Hi,
The speedometer on my Kawasaki has been acting up for quite a while. It sometimes jumps all over the place never showing a correct or clear speed but most of the times it shows zero. This bike uses the ABS sensors to measure speed! I've measured both sensors, which show the same resistance. Replaced the rear one which didn't change anything.
What i've figured out is that if i unplug the front sensor, drive a few meters and then plug it back in it works fine as long as the ignition doesn't turn off for more than a few seconds. I will try to ride for an extended time tomorrow to rule out bad connections as the problem. Seeing as the bike clearly knows the speed, but refuses to display it to me (and doesn't count towards the odometer) i'm thinking it's a ECU fault, but i have minimal experience with those parts of a bike. Would love opinions and possible solutions, or more ways to troubleshoot, things to check for!
Bike is 2020 Z125 (not pro version)
Thanks!

Different sensor combinations:
Front only, works if unplugged and replugged if ignition is on. ABS light
Both plugged, no speed
Rear only, no speed, ABS light
Both unplugged, no speed, ABS light, engine light

Content:
I'm planning on taking a motorcycle road trip in late Spring or early summer, by myself and with no specific time limit to be away from home. I'm getting older, and will be turning 81 about the time I can leave, and feel like this well might be the last such trip I will get to make. I plan on heading west from where I live in Rockford, IL and get at least as far as the Black Hills area in South Dakota, visiting Crazy Horse, Mt. Rushmore, the Badlands and maybe Devils Tower in Wyoming.

My question for anyone who knows this route is, would it be a good ride to just take U.S. 20 straight west until mid Nebraska, then head north to the Black Hills. I really don't want to use the Interstates, but not sure that U.S. 20 would be any more scenic or interesting. Options would be to either head north into Minnessotta before heading West, or south and then come across Iowa and into Nebraska before heading north. But again, I would prefer to avoid the Interstates.

Any suggestions or advice? I had hoped to have some company for the trip but my old riding friends are either dead, given up riding or just not up to a long road trip.

Title: CG 125 2002 ? Identification problems
Author: AshCG125

Content:
Hey guys, got a weird one here, looking for some insight perhaps. Please keep in mind, I am a beginner motorcyclist, but I am trying my best to learn how to ride AND maintain these amazing machines!
Just traded a 2002 Honda Shadow 750 Spirit to a kid who was getting rid of a 2001 Yamaha R1 1000. Apparently it was too fast for him and he really just wanted a cruiser, okay. Bike has a few cosmetic dings, nothing I'm worried about, and also needs a new battery (The current one is so bad that headlights don't even stay consistently bright during a drive, and you cannot start without a jump), which is only gonna run 50 dollars. However, one thing he said was that the previous owner had put an aftermarket slip-on exhaust on the bike, and now the "bike needs a tune up to unlock the full power of the bike", which sounded like dookie to me.
Having 0 experience with slip-on's, i decided to test the bike, and god does it have no power! If I attempt to get the bike going from a standstill at anything lower then 5k RPM, the bike will almost certainly stall if i don't pull the clutch immediately, and even moving in first gear, wide open throttle, RPM's increase very slowly and it can take up to 10-20 seconds just to get to 70-ish MPH. At some point the RPM's can reach redline, and at some point I can exceed 100 MPH or more, but there ain't no way this is caused by a simple slip-on, I'm not that dense.
Tomorrow morning I am going to pull the slip-on off and do a quick test, see if it ACTUALLY has that kind of impact, but on the chance that I am right and its not the exhaust, what could possibly be doing this to this poor bike? Part of me wants to assume it is related to the clutch because acceleration is so poor, but at the same time if it was the clutch, the RPM's would go up but speed wouldnt.. right?
Any and all help is appreciated. Thank you guys so much!

Unlock the ultimate riding adventure at the 2024 Georgia Mountain Rally! Seize this moment to join us from May 3rd to 5th at the stunning Georgia Mountain Fairgrounds in Hiawassee for an unforgettable weekend. Positioned mere minutes from iconic routes like Deal‚Äôs Gap, the Cherohala Skyway, and the Blue Ridge Parkway, and surrounded by a plethora of forest roads, Hiawassee is a rider's paradise, catering to every skill level.

Your registration unlocks a weekend of lakeside camping under the stars, complete with convenient amenities. Prefer a bit more comfort? Explore nearby accommodations ‚Äî from motels to cabins ‚Äî at special rates, easily accessible via link on our event page.

Dive into a packed schedule featuring savory chili and steak dinners, hearty pancake breakfasts, guided rides across both paved roads and dirt trails, and enriching seminars. Not to mention, the chance to win fantastic prizes and enjoy the camaraderie of fellow motorcycle enthusiasts.

Content: Those who know he pleasure of riding small bikes. Let's back up a little bit. born 1960 started riding 67 or 68. On a Honda like so Many of us. The Great American Revolution of learning about Freedom! I have had a few Bikes Mostly Honda's. But have tried and do like other Brands, Just not HD! Since 17' ive have 2 Indians. A Road Master & Chief. Both serve a specific purpose Roadmaster Wonderful Touring bike when by myself or wife on Back1 The Chief has a Side car for a different type of Traveling! One I Holly Embrace. The Hannigan has served me well! too! But I Bring this all up for in 20 I bought a Honda Monkey! More fun then 1 man can imagine! Content:
Hi All
Just joined. I'm hoping to get over to the UK this summer, buy a Super Cub and head to Scandinavia. I'm 75 with 60 Years riding experience. My last ride was a month around Puerto Rico in January. Have ridden in all 6 rideable continents and 38 countries. Often one or both of my daughters traveled with me. I have a RE Himalayan, a KLR650 and a Sportster 48. All are heavily customized to accommodate my needs such as back rest, heel and toe shifter, windshield, aftermarket seats and 3 point lighting front and back for all.
I have two questions for anyone who knows and would like to enlighten me.
#1 will I have any trouble buying this bike and insuring in the UK at my age?
#2 have read various reports on windshields for the Cub and a number of people have mentioned flex in a negative way because of illdesigned mounting. If you have a windshield and it works great for you I'd like to know please
Fortunately I have family in Kent so I will be storing it with them after the trip and it'll be ready for the next ride. Right now I'm interested in Eastern Europe and Scandinavia. This trip will be to Scandinavia so if you have any relevant info I'd be happy to hear it. All my trips have been on secondary roads. I'm always looking for out of the way roads with little truck traffic so I can cruise without worrying.
Glad to be hear on the forum and if the bike turns out to be just my cup of tea I'll be getting one here too. Here being Colorado.

Content:
Hi all
I am new to motorcycle maintenance, and recently did a some work on my Honda cbf250 front fork.
I stripped the fork down and disassembled to fix leaking fork oil seals.

One of the forks went down no problem, however the second damper retension bolt got stripped managed to get the bolt off by using a size up imperial Alan, which actually seems to get good purchase.

I stripped the fork and replaced the seals. This is where I get uncertain.

im going on a long trip (2 days ride, 11 hours) tommorow, and due to the time constraint, decided not to replace the bolt. I couldn‚Äôt torque it due to lack of imperial Alan sockets, but I tightened it quite tight (aiming for about the same tension I applied to the other fork tube using a torque wrench) and applied blue lock tight. It feels pretty bomb, I think I could get it out currently, but it wouldn‚Äôt be super easy tightness wise.

basically I‚Äôm wondering:

A: would people think it‚Äôs likely for this bolt to loosen? My mate said stripped bolts tension unreliably, which makes me worried about the bolt loosening. I feel like it‚Äôs tight enough, if anything I‚Äôd be concerned about over tightening, but I‚Äôm new so unsure.
B: if it did loosen, how dangerous would that be?
I don‚Äôt care if it would cause damage, damage can be fixed. But I don‚Äôt want to lose my front wheel at 100 km/h.

I'm currently planning on seeing if I can find a replacement bolt anywhere around town and if I can I‚Äôll probably pull it and replace for peace of mind, but if that fails I‚Äôd like to guage risk?
Thanks,
James.

Title: From San Antonio Texas.

Content:
Updated 2/15/2024 below / Solved!

Long time/long ago rider returning to the sport.
My new bike has a well-known turbulence problem with the windscreen. Am addressing that separately.
In the meantime, am dealing with it using earplugs which always use anyway.
Full face Shoei RF1400 type.
Was using silicone tiered plugs that were ok, but then switched to foam due to the increased decibel rating.
Yikes! They actually AMPLIFIED the wind, turbulence, and even engine sound. I road for about 30 minutes and had to keep ducking lower behind the screen to reduce the pain of the roar and popping. I didn‚Äôt understand why this was happening. Thought I hadn‚Äôt inserted them correctly, and pulled over a couple times to reinstall. ‚Äîhave been a rider and previous firearms dealer for many years, so I‚Äôve stuck in a few earplugs.
Never had this issue before. It was so bad that I finally had to pull over and go back to silicone, but not before causing lingering ear pressure sensation and still ringing 2 days later.
So my question is: What the hell?

Content:
Hey I just got my first project bike, 82 CB900, and am wondering where i start. Besides cleaning the gas tank im not exactly sure what to do. The engine cranks but and would probably run if i had the gas tank attached. I imagine the carbs need to be cleaned, but I'm mainly trying to figure out what needs to be replaced vs works. The bike hasn't been running for about 9 years. I have most the parts that aren't in the picture they're just not on the bike.
Also any websites or youtubers you guys use would be appreciated.
On top of that I am thinking of streaming working on the bike once I know what to do. Thinking of doing that because I imagine other people probably know more and could help me out in live time that way.
Thank you all for reading
Update: spent a day looking at stuff, waiting on some tools to run tests, but coils came back reading 2.5 ohms but didn't see any spark when i took the cable off the spark plug and held it to a ground. Also all 3 calipers are frozen so that will be another thing to learn how to do.
Second Update: Made sure wires were tightened and i did see spark, i was able to get the outside ones off, but i couldn't check the inside spark plugs, didn't have the right size socket so i have to figure out what size it was, read it was a rounded 18mm but when I get ahold of a shop manual I'll know for sure.

Content:
Recently purchased a 2008 VT750 Shadow Aero Trike that basically bogs down (cutting out) when attempting speeds exceeding 50+mph. It is literally throttling down and stalling until the speed drops below this mark. I then have to have to downshift and work the throttle in order to keep it from shutting down.
Had it serviced where the service technician found the TPS (throttle position sensor) shorted open as well as two vacuum leaks on two open ports. The carburetor was rebuilt, the TPS set to spec, spark plugs replaced, checked valve clearance, rode with timing light on - did not loose spark, checked flywheel to crank position and swapped computer out and was rechecked for malfunction. After this service it is now cutting out at 60-65mph. Any thoughts and suggestions?

Hi. My name is John, and I have a problem with buying old motorcycles. Been riding since 2012, and I've had 7 bikes, 3 of which still live and run (of the other 4, 3 were sold and my first, '79 Honda CM400T is a trophy above my workbench).

2nd. '04 Honda shadow. (Bought off a fellow marine because his wife was pregnant. 1st ex wife took it in the divorce.)

4th. '84 Honda Goldwing (I miss it, but bad knees meant I couldn't hold it up anymore. Full dressed. Sold to a neighbor)

6th. 2002 Suzuki Intruder 1400 (talked girlfriend into getting it. She named it Blueberry because it's blue.)
7th. 1998 Suzuki Intruder 1500 (named SugarLoaf. She is GREEN.)

Content:
Hello everyone,

I'm seeking advice for an issue with my 2018 Yamaha Xmax 400, which has clocked 62,000 kilometers.
Recently, I started experiencing engine "knocking" sounds. My mechanic diagnosed it as a failed crankshaft. Consequently, both the crankshaft and piston were replaced. The scooter was picked up from the repair on January 17, 2024, and I was advised to keep it under 80 km/h for the first 1,000 kilometers, which I adhered to.
Everything seemed fine for the first 466 kilometers, but then I encountered an issue when it was wet and raining; my scooter would shut off when slowing down or nearly stopping, as if the engine was choking.
The mechanic initially thought it was a loose connection in the air lifter intake to the engine and fixed it.
However, the problem persisted.

Today, after the plug was replaced, the issue occurred again on my way back home, and this time there was no rain or wet road (see attached video). I'm quite despaired as the repair cost me $2,500.

Has anyone experienced a similar issue or could possibly pinpoint what might be causing this problem?

Any advice or suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you in advance for your help!

Content:
I bought a Kawi z900 a couple of months ago. It is more powerful than what I have ridden before so I gradually try to learn how to cope with the acceleration. Have a good seating position etc.

Just to learn, I sometimes roll about 12.5 mph in first gear with clutch pressed. I then rev a little and drop the clutch. If I rev to 5000 and drop the clutch, the bike makes a small jerk forward, but the front wheel stays on the ground. The bike rises a little on the fork.

12.5 mph corresponds to 2000 rpm, so I "over rev" by about 3000. If I increase the revs to 6-7000 I expect to see a baby wheelie, but I haven'y tried that yet.

I will not take up stunting, but I want to feel absolutely relaxed and in control when I drop the clutch at a moderate over rev. Just learning to control the acceleration.

I do the same in second gear at 30 mph and revving to 6000 rpm (about 2000 rpm too much).

What do you say about this exercise? Is it a safe way of learning as long as you are in control of the rpms.

Content:
Hello! I just got a motorcycle and while the ride is great, the gas tank has a few visual flaws. In particular, it has a few rusty chips, scratches and oxidation. I did a lot of research and hoped someone could confirm my game plan or help me with suggestions:
1. Working on the chips. I would start sanding the rust out of them with 400 sand paper, apply a primer (if there are any recommended, please let me know). After letting it try for 2 hours I paint the holes in new color (I got a matching color online) and after letting that dry for another 2 hours I apply the clear coat.
2. Working on scratches. I‚Äôll start with thoroughly cleaning the tank and use cleaning alcohol as last step. Then I use 1500 sandpaper (wet) and work on the areas that are scratched. Then I switch up to 2000 wet sandpaper and afterwards clean everything with cleaning alcohol again. I get a polish machine and use maquires ultimate compound to polish the entire tank. That should also fix the oxidation.
3. Waxing. After 2 weeks of waiting I wax the entire tank.
Happy about any recommendations, since I‚Äòve never done it before. Thanks!

Author: Joshua Bradley

Content: Hi there, My name is John & my nick name is Madrugada, I am 73 years old, I am Scottish by birth & have lived in the South of Spain for the last 20 years. I have ridden motorcycles since 1966, mainly in the cold, rain & snow in the North, now I'm playing out my motorbiking days in the warm Climate of the Costa Del Sol. Having said that, I was on the point of hanging up my boots & helmet as I have lost a lot of confidence & stability after some health issues. I'm OK now, great in fact & I am keen to stay on the road, so I've bought a sidecar & stuck it on the side of my bike which is a BMW F650 GS. My intention is to carry on touring Europe little by little, obviously with the sidecar on it is totally different to riding a bike, a bit weird, in fact, but much more stable & slower...........great fun though. I belong to a motorcycle club here in Spain & they are all old geezers like me & we are all of the same mind, touring, staying on hotels & enjoying the various European cultures. I look forward to a good relationship with other members, with or without sidecars. Cheers, John.

Content:
Hello, new rider here, have about 900km under my belt, passed my basic learners test, with about three weeks of riding in. FYI

Have been trying to ride a variety of roads/freeways and build up some experience in all conditions.

Today went for my longest ride and half way through it, was riding a very hilly area with some lovely turns. I noticed on a lot of corners on some of the roads that I took there were was a build of loose stones in the middle of my lane, both along the flat and around the corners. I was ok on the straight, managed to ride either side of it. However in a couple of turns, was lightly braking into the corner avoided the stones, but on one such corner there were stones in middle and my front wheel was under a light brake, however just started to slide as I came across it. Fortunately I wasn't going that fast throughout corner, I released the front brake, and the bike sat up and I managed to get through corner just, however it really shook me up. It was way too close to losing complete control and crashing.

What can you do, when you are wide turning into a corner and notice stones in the middle of your intended line whilst braking (front only) across it. I saw the stones only in the turn late as they were shaded by over hanging large trees.

Love any thoughts or suggestions on this.
Thanks Andy

Author: camachoash21

Content:
I'm new to riding, about 4 months now and recently I've been having this issue with my bike. It's a yamaha v-star 250 from 2012 with about 8100 km on it. I've been riding in cold weather so far anywhere from -2 to 8 degrees celsius. Had a similar issue with the motorcycle about 2 weeks ago when I was on my way to my friend's house (which is 50 km away) where it just died on a hill after spluttering and it would not start back up (it would start for about 10 seconds then it would just die). I got my friend who is a mechanic and we checked the air filters, changed the spark plugs, checked all connections and the battery then figured that after spraying starting fluid in the motorcycle it would come back to life, so he said that it's a big chance the carburetor jets are clogged (which they were), we took apart the motorcycle and fully cleaned the carburetor and there were a lot of jets that were clogged. After that the motorcycle ran perfectly and I drove the 50km back to my home with no problems in 1 degree weather. Fast forward to now 2 weeks later and I'm having issues again, I was on the way to my university today when the motorcycle just started spluttering then it just straight up died in the middle of the road. Had to go on the sidewalk and try to start it back up again. Wouldn't start but after a few minutes of trying it started back up with the choke, then i lowered the choke and it ran fine. After that I decided to try to make it to my university which was only 1 km left away and just as i was about to reach it, the motorcycle died again. Spluttered and then died. Did the same thing, went on the side and had the motorcycle run on full choke. This time the RPMS were getting really high, then getting really low, and it would do this for a few minutes until it just came back to life and sounded normal. After that I went to park it. When I got back to my motorcycle (2 hours later) I started with the choke full (everything fine) warmed it up for 5 minutes until I could feel the heat coming from the side and left with bike. 3 minutes later it just died again the same way it died previously, this time after starting it back up it would do the same thing, splutter then die when coming to a stop sign. Somebody came by and tried to help me with the bike, we adjusted the idling speed of the bike and turned it to the right. Did not help. He also told me that he has a carburetor bike as well and has the same problem when riding in cold weather. Got any ideas what this could be? any help would be appreciated

Also I would like to mention that every time I go out riding in the rain my motorcycle start having the same issues, it seems to splutter and then die at low rpm in the rain. Fuel pump was not opened up and cleaned, we did take the line off and cranked it and it did push out fuel at a steady rate. The motorcycle did not sit in garage for longer than 1-2 days when it was snowing, I've gone out with the motorcycle pretty much every single day if it didn't snow.

I broke a part of my clutch lever off the other day and finally got around to installing a new one but I can‚Äôt get the screw or the nut holding the old one in place to budge.

The head for the screw is pretty munted but it still turns. The nut turns fine as well. But I‚Äôve tried every combination over and over - holding the nut still and turning the screw; holding the screw still and turning the nut; turning both at the same time - but neither the screw nor the nut will tighten or loosen from the position they are in. I guess the nut isn‚Äôt threading on the screw properly and is just jammed in the same position.

Any suggestions for getting this screw and nut holding my clutch lever in place loose?

Title: Screw and nut holding clutch lever in place won‚Äôt budge
Author: Leem

Content:
and you have installed cylinder heads...
Bolting it back together, you have to torque the headbolts, making sure to do it in a cross pattern according to the manual.

My Dad the mechanical engineer had some advice, I wonder what you think.
1) Tighten the head bolts in stages to the proper torque.
2) Once you have them tightened, loosen all boots again, (in stages)
3) repeat number one.

According to him, this helps to "lessen" or elimiminate any residual stress.

Anyone else do this?

Content:
Hey guys. I‚Äôm brand new. No! I‚Äôm not even brand new‚Ä¶. I‚Äôve never ridden a motorcycle before and I‚Äôm almost 50.

I‚Äôve been on bicycles for a long time. I‚Äôll do long 60 mile road cycling adventures and enjoy black diamond mountain bike trails, even if I‚Äôm not the most aggressive.
I LOVE biking.
For years now, I‚Äôve wanted to step that love of bikes up to motorcycles but‚Ä¶. I‚Äôve always decided against it because of the lack of safety.
Now, I‚Äôm ready to take that step. I want to get a bike. I‚Äôm thinking along the lines of an adventure bike like a KTM or BMW or something but, in all honesty, would likely end up using it more for my long freeway commute and some open country asphalt rides on days off. So‚Ä¶ cruiser, adventure bike, eventually touring bike‚Ä¶. Definitely not sport bike. (Not interested in racing.)

im TALL. 6‚Äô5‚Äù

ok so, I am ready to start getting into it but‚Ä¶.. as I‚Äôve said, I‚Äôve only SAT on a motorcycle once or twice in my life, never ridden one. In order to get started, I need to go over the most basic practices you could imagine.
So my question is‚Ä¶. How can I do this? I can‚Äôt test ride a bike at a dealer (or private seller) without having sole basic practice under my belt. I can‚Äôt pick up a cheap used beater if I don‚Äôt know how to ride it home lol.
So where can I go to start this process? Are there used dealers that would deal with a person with my total lack of experience?
Are there classes that provide bikes to learn on?

thanks in advance. Don‚Äôt judge me! üòÇ

Title: Blke
Author: brianfulton52

Content:
Hey there, everybody!

I'm restoring a Yamaha Road Star, and I had smoke coming from my 2-1 exhaust and backfires galore again after I did a valve adjustment. The exhaust valves on the rear cylinder as well as the intake valves of the front cylinder were fine. I had a theory that oil was getting into the rear cylinder some how, so I took the junction off the exhaust system and left two wide open pipes for me to confirm that the rear cylinder is the culprit for the smoke, and the front for the backfires.

What I discovered was exactly that, but also that the rear cylinder isn't even firing. Frankly, I'm embarrassed that I didn't discover this sooner, but it is what it is. Then I took the head off of the rear cylinder and this is what I found.




If I'd only had been working with daylight instead of garage lights when I was adjusting the valves I'd have probably noticed the discoloration even with the valve spacer where it was. I was only expecting bad piston rings, and I didn't get look into that further; not that it matters since I've already got two sets of the oem piston rings on the way. I've decided that I'm just gonna replace all the gaskets from the bottom-most gaskets on up, replace both pistons' rings, and, now, I guess that I'm replacing the exhaust valves and cleaning the valve seats. I don't know. I haven't been able to inspect it further, except from the pictures and from the discoloration I can tell that one exhaust valve in particular is responsible

What I'm interpreting from all of this is that combustion is getting into the valve chamber. So that means that valves were stuck open during combustion. Or, that oil is coming up from the piston rings and is mucking up the combustion by soaking and interfering with the spark plugs, which leads to leftover gasoline getting up into the valve chamber and burning up in there? What does this look like to folks who do this for a living?

Content:
My KTM Duke 125 (18 plate) wont at all turn on, when i turn the key NOTHING happens, no lights, nothing on the display, and obviously the bike doesn't start. I road to work with absolutely no issues after only 6hrs shift i went to get fuel (i work at Tesco so was a few hundred yrds) absolutely fine. I then filled up with fuel (yes definitely petrol) and it went off once, i turned the key on and off, and it came back then few seconds later it went back off. Also a weird thing is that when it first happened and i hit the bike out of frustration the lights flashed on for a second.

Now i have checked the battery and its fine, even charged it to make sure, have checked the fuses they're all in tact, i have checked all the connections and tried my best to check the ones near the ignition barrel and they all seem fine. There is absolutely no sign of life no matter what i do now. I am assuming it is an electrical problem, maybe something wrong with the ignition barrel or a wire connecting to it.
And no it is not the kill switch.

Any help would be greatly appreciated because i am stumped right now!

Author: Steadfastly

Content:
Does anyone else have this problem?

My small town has become so inundated with transplants from EVERYWHERE, that for the first time in my long life, I feel as if it's too dangerous to ride. People who come here drive far too fast and angry, tailgating, passing on corners, and slamming into many, rear-ending others at lights and stop signs because they are either under the influence of alcohol and drugs, or have their eyes and fingers on their cell phones. We have auto and MC deaths almost weekly, and we are a town of around 12K is all.

I say "Trapped" because I live on the Olympic Peninsula in WA state, and almost no country roads that go any distance. The Olympics on one side and beaches on the other. The main highway is a death trap. If I ride the death trap to leave the Peninsula, it runs right into a far worse death trap...the Tacoma and Seattle area.

My wife, kinda' the boss...says I cannot buy another bike and ride unless we move to Montana or Idaho in the country. I could play hard ass and do it anyway but think she's probably right. So far, over 50 years of dirt, race and road riding, and it never sent me to the hospital. But I can feel it coming in this rat race. And at 70 years old, I hate the thought of moving again, and also feel I need to be on a bike until I croak..but not croak on the street due to some idiot. CONUNDRUM!

Anyone else here that can't escape riding with the odds stacked against you?

Okay, enough ranting and poor, pitiful me stuff. Maybe I just need a hug or a new prostate.
Breadcrumbs:
Home
Forums

from exhaust in Tenere 700.
A sunny and quick ride out to one of the beaches in my area.

Content:
Greetings all.

Last summer, dipped my toe into the water by picking up a 1985 Virago 900 to see if I really wanted to get back into bikes. Well, the bike gods bit again so a few weeks ago, I picked up a 2019 Suzuki Boulevard c50T with only 1,000 miles on the dial. Put 500 miles on her in the last few weeks getting familiar with the bike and making the modifications we all make with a new purchase. Obviously, the Virago will go to the next custodian for future ownership.

Mods include replacing stock seat with a 2 up Saddlemen Explorer. Definitely improves the ride. LED headlight and turn signal upgrade, Kewig waterproof wireless cellphone charger/holder, wired for and purchased heated gloves (I live in the NJ so winter riding is cold), aftermarket luggage rack, Graber passenger Armrests, mechanical throttle lock, fork deflectors and windshield extender to eliminate buffeting at speed.

Heres what I can say about the boulevard c50T. It's a good middleweight cruiser. Light enough to enjoy the twisties (650 lbs) and powerful enough to stay at 70-75 all day long. Much beyond that, the missing 6th gear becomes obvious and vibration introduces itself. Don't get me wrong, Im not dissing the bike. I get my speed fix on 4 wheels on racetracks in the warmer months so motorcycles north of 75 mph isn't necessary for me. I will say this - For relatively short money, I got into a bike I would have no problem doing 300 mile days (note previous seat upgrade. Wouldn't even attempt on stock seat). Much more than that, your gonna want a few hundred more cc's and a 6th gear at least.

Im really looking forward to the weather breaking in a few months so the wife and I can head out for a few long weekends or even impromptu day trips.

If you've read this far, thanks for doing so. Feel free to comment.

Best,

Jim

Content: Occasionally I need to use a cell phone or gps with gloves on which are not made to be capacitive screen friendly. I bought this stainless steel thread from Amazon https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B079H26WBN/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1. This thread can be sewn (even by those with no sewing talent) into the leather end of a finger on a glove. The idea is to make a mass of thread at the end of the finger that is on both the outside and inside surface of the glove finger. It will operate a capacitive screen, as on a gps or phone. I used a short section of 1/2" PVC pipe to stuff into the glove finger to aid the sewing; it makes it easier to avoid accidentally sewing the finger too short. Probably a bad idea to try with heated gloves.

Content:
Running 14 gauge accessory wires today I used landscape drip-line tubing as a housing/casing.
It fit perfectly enough that 6-foot lengths fed through easily but snug.
That landscape drip tube is pretty tough stuff (enough to prevent a wire from getting pinched or abraded) and with the fit it gives a much cleaner install than corrugated shell stuff or a rubber sleeve like OEM.
On the bike you can see the plastic drip line tubing running from the rear up to the front, housing power wires.
